The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 11th report of the Standing Committee on Petitions for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 10 May 2023, 24 May 2023, 31 May 2023 and 14 June 2023.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 43 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 5 petitioners—requesting the cessation of ethnic discrimination in handling the Afghan Humanitarian visa applications (EN5031)
From 33 petitioners—requesting the cessation of the habitual systemic failure of the real estate industry (EN5033)
From 3 petitioners—requesting that IMMI Account Ensure be 100 per cent operational from 9am to 5pm on Monday to Friday (EN5034)
From 19 petitioners—requesting Centrelink payments and domestic violence (EN5041)
From 279 petitioners—requesting a federally funded scheme for customers affected by the builder's liquidation (EN5044)
From 9 petitioners—requesting the cessation of inequality of funding for psychology (EN5045)
From 55697 petitioners—requesting Australia rejects amendments to the 75th WHA/WHO International Health Regulations (EN5048)
From 5 petitioners—requesting that Skill Assessment not be expired. (EN5055)
From 10 petitioners—requesting that mental health medications in Australiabe banned (EN5057)
From 12 petitioners—requesting that all unions pay tax now (EN5058)
From 23 petitioners—requesting no Apartheid in Australia / racist Voice (EN5059)
From 37 petitioners—requesting the B.O.M. publish accurate Australian temperatures (EN5060)
From 3 petitioners—requesting Prime Minister must attend the NATO Summit in July 2023 (EN5061)
From 29 petitioners—requesting a Royal Commission into price gouging of petrol prices be established (EN5062)
From 9 petitioners—requesting the flood-proofing of Cabonne (EN5065)
From 8 petitioners—requesting the purchase of nuclear powered vessels including submarines be banned (EN5066)
From 54 petitioners—requesting an inquiry into the cost of living crisis (EN5068)
From 17 petitioners—regarding Peter Dutton's eligibility to sit. (EN5069)
From 152 petitioners—regarding voting No to the Voice (EN5070)
From 35 petitioners—requesting the flying of foreign flags on government property be banned (EN5071)
From 29 petitioners—requesting more research and resources for eating disorders such as anorexia (EN5075)
From 3 petitioners—requesting a limit on the number of petitions per individual (EN5076)
From 33 petitioners—requesting the Stage 3 tax cuts be scrapped (EN5077)
From 1278 petitioners—requesting the national newborn screening election commitment be implemented as promised (EN5078)
From 342 petitioners—regarding living costs and jobs creation in relation to offshore gas exploration (EN5079)
From 12 petitioners—requesting the removal of the 60 days dispensing proposal from the May Federal Budget (EN5080)
From 79 petitioners—regarding the fighting in Sudan (EN5081)
From 15 petitioners—requesting it be made mandatory for Australian banks to implement 2FA and login alerts (EN5083)
From 14963 petitioners—requesting an increase for research scholarship rates for PhD students (EN5085)
From 16 petitioners—requesting vary preferential voting in the Senatebe varied (EN5087)
From 8 petitioners—requesting a permanent Army presence in the Northwest of Australia (EN5088)
From 21 petitioners—requesting the gross income for the GST threshold be increased (EN5089)
From 12028 petitioners—requesting fenfluramine be added to the PBS for patients with DRAVET Syndrome (EN5090)
From 21 petitioners—requesting independent pharmacies be saved (EN5091)
From 1381 petitioners—requesting no funding for the AFL stadium in Tasmania (EN5092)
From 265 petitioners—requesting TSMIT for current 491 visa holders and pending applicationsbe kept (EN5093)
From 7 petitioners—regarding another PR deportation in full breach of M32/2022 and S81/2022 (EN5096)
From 54 petitioners—regarding the nuclear submarines and AUKUS deal (EN5099)
From 19 petitioners—requesting funding of scientists to resolve the climate threat to the Earth (EN5101)
From 34 petitioners—requesting vaping not be banned (EN5102)
From 802 petitioners—requesting the cessation of federal funding for Gold Coast Light Rail Stage 4 (EN5103)
From 146 petitioners—requesting CGM for all insulin-dependent diabetics including Type 2 diabetics be full subsidised (EN5105)
From 6556 petitioners—regarding Australia's duty of care to people in Australia seeking asylum (PN0563)

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, and in accordance with standing order 207, I present the following 43 petitions:
Refugee and Humanitarian Program: Afghanistan
Australia is proudly built on Multiculturalism, STOP the apparent ethnic bias by the Australian Government in handling Afghan Humanitarian Visas.
All Afghan ethnic groups have served and sacrificed their lives within the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan and its allied international troops including Australian Defence Force.

As result of their services to the coalition forces, many Afghans from all ethnic backgrounds are actively being pursued by Taliban. They have been captured, detained, unlawfully killed and their property, bank accounts, and assets have been seized as spoils of war.
Recent reports by human rights organisations include terror stories from all corners of Afghanistan, affecting all ethnic groups.
The Afghan population living in Australia consists of various ethnic groups. We ask to end the institutionalised biases in favour of one group and/or against other groups.

Australian Afghans have sponsored their loved ones whose cases might be at the mercy of the recent discriminatory policy of the Department of Home Affairs. It focuses on pre-defined priority groups in clear contravention of the refugee conventions. Australia's obligation under those conventions are being undermined by the policy.
Afghans who are inside Afghanistan for reasons beyond their control are being rejected due to the geographic disposition.
We therefore ask the House to ensure humanitarian visas are granted on the basis of merit, undertaking adequate risk assessments and other eligible criteria.

The signatories of this petition want the Australian government to take a non-discriminatory approach to processing of Afghan Humanitarian visa applications. There should be no favouritism towards a particular Afghan ethnic group.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5031)
Housing
Australians are in renter hell, and it's only going to get worse.
More than 51% of Aussie renters have "nowhere to escape" as they face extreme conditions from mould infestations and leaking roofs to non-potable water and uninhabitable conditions.
Our rental laws are among the worst in the world. Almost a third of Aussie renters live in worse than third world conditions.
Real estate agents and landlords hold ransom for the roof over tenants heads rather than maintaining minimum housing standards, completing routine maintenance and carrying out emergency repairs.

51% of people who rent are currently living in a home that needs repairs. 68% of Australians who rent are concerned that a request for repairs could mean a rent increase and 44% are concerned a request for repairs could get them evicted from their homes.

We therefore ask the House to call for a Royal Commission into the habitual systemic failure of the real estate industry and their lessor's obligations and a Parliamentary Committee Hearing on Australian minimum housing standards.

We, the undersigned and concerned citizens who are deeply troubled by the current state of rental housing in Australia, believe that every person has the right to safe, secure, and healthy housing, and that it is the responsibility of the government to ensure that this right is upheld.
We remind you that we live in a representative democracy, whereas the representatives are elected by the people, for the people; and are entrusted to carry out the business of good governance.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN5033)
Department of Home Affairs: IMMIAccount

IMMI Account is the online platform to lodge visa applications. Given that the IMMI Account is experiencing so many ERRORS and is down during work hours (9 to 5), we request that there is an increase to the capacity of their server or website to ensure that at least the IMMI Account can be 100% fully operational during work hours between 9am to 5pm Monday to Friday.
All Migration Agents and Lawyers are very frustrated at the IMMI Account being down as it interferes with the ability to get work done and productivity is significantly slowed down.
Now is the time to ACT because there has been too many errors and the IMMI Account has been DOWN too much during 9am to 5pm Monday to Friday.
We therefore ask the House to ENSURE the IMMI Account is 100% FULLY operational between 9am to 5pm Monday to Friday and ensure NO errors and it is NOT down at ALL during these work hours.
We request that there is an increase in FUNDING to the capacity of their server, website of the IMMI Account.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5034)
Pensions and Benefits
A person should have the right to their own financial independence.

After talking with my OMC at Centrelink today, it's clear less and less people "pool" resources. Given we live in the age of information, it makes sense why this is the case, and is something I have both experienced—and seen other people experience.
Domestic violence.
The reality is, a person in a relationship with no financial independence, is at a much higher risk of experiencing domestic violence.
The risk is even greater for vulnerable groups such as (but not limited to!): Disabled and/or elderly people, very young people, single parents, and women.
As it stands right now, to be ineligible for the maximum coupled payment, your partner only has to earn per week, a tiny:
Jobseeker: $706 ($638 after tax).
Parenting: $1,142.50 ($973.42 after tax).
Everyone in the household is expected to cover all expenses on this singular amount.
If the person on benefits has a medical condition, or children to another partner for example, this causes much greater stress, as these hugely decrease discretionary (if any) income.
According to the ABS, 16.3% of women, and 7.8% of men experiencing DV, experience economic abuse.
The ABS acknowledges these statistics are highly unreliable. The reasons are obvious to anyone with common sense.
We therefore ask the House to completely remove partner income tests, and allow people to be seen as individuals with the right to their own financial freedom, independent of any other person.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN5041)
Housing

The impacts of COVID-19 is still rampant in the construction industry across Australia. The Federal Government has acknowledged that there is a national housing crisis and has already committed to increase housing supply as a matter of national interest and to reduce homelessness. Unfortunately, due to rising inflation and over-stimulus in the construction sector, shortage of skilled staff, rising cost of living and other global factors, many Australians are experiencing the additional financial and emotional hardship of finding a new builder to finish their house after the collapse of several residential builders across Australia. More recently, more than 1700 Porter Davis customers will encounter financial hardship in finishing their home through no fault of their own. The Federal Government has a duty to ensure that these houses are finished in a timely manner to free up housing stock. The Government also as a responsibility to support customers given the lack of consumer protection in the construction industry.

We therefore ask the House to introduce the Home Rescue Guarantee scheme to cover the difference in cost of finishing incomplete homes in exchange for a percentage stake in the build that can be repaid by the customers once they are in a financial position to do so. This will allow customers to minimise unexpected out of pocket expenses and give them a real chance to move into their dream home. On a national level, the scheme will ensure increased housing stock and is financially sustainable for people to access.
from 279 citizens (Petition No. EN5044)
Higher Education Loan Program

Australia is in the midst of a mental health crisis. Training more psychologists is one part of the solution. All Master of Psychology courses train students towards achieving General Registration as Psychologists. Changes to university funding has resulted in some Masters courses costing students nearly four times as much as others.

Inequality already exists within psychology in Australia with the disparity in Medicare rebates between Clinical and all other Psychologists. This inequality and disparity now extends to tertiary courses, with Organisational Psychology classified as Funding Cluster 1—all other postgraduate Psychology (and all other Allied Health) courses are classified as Cluster 2 programs.

Studying a Master of Psychology with a specialisation in Organisational Psychology now contributes in excess of $30,000 to a student's HELP debt, compared to less than $10,000 for Masters courses in other streams. This extreme financial impediment poses an existential threat to the profession of Organisational Psychology in Australia, and exacerbates the inequality and inaccessibility of psychology in Australia.

This stark disparity discriminates against students working towards alleviating the mental health crisis in areas including return to work and rehabilitation, workplace stress, burnout and wellbeing, career guidance, employee satisfaction, among many other areas which are the focus of Organisational Psychology.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Reclassify ALL Master of Psychology programs together in Funding Cluster 2;
2. Students incurring stifling fees from M.Psych (Organisational) programs from 2021 to have a revised, standardised contribution amount backdated to their HELP accounts.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN5045)
International Health Regulations
We request that Parliament vote on whether to accept or reject the amendments to the International Health Regulations (2005) that were adopted by the 75th World Health Assembly on 27 May 2022.

Every nation, including Australia, has the authority to reject these amendments under Article 61 of the IHR, but any such rejection must be within 18 months of their adoption. This must be done before the end of November 2023.

The changes to Article 59 of the IHR would shorten the time for future amendments to enter into force from 24 to 12 months and would shorten the period of time for rejection or reservations to be submitted from 18 to 10 months.
We object to these changes.
The amendments to the IHR that were adopted on 27 May 2022 have not been debated in or voted on by Parliament.
This is compounded by the fact that an additional 307 proposed amendments are currently being negotiated by the Working Group on Amendments to the International Health Regulations (WGIHR).
The people of Australia have not had an opportunity to express their opinions regarding these legally-binding changes to international law.

We therefore ask the House to respect the will of the people of Australia and vote to reject the amendments to the International Health Regulations that were adopted by the World Health Assembly on 27 May 2022.
from 55,697 citizens (Petition No. EN5048)
Skilled Migration

There should be no skill assessment expiry date ones someone achieve it. Specially for people who have completed through job ready program. Because ones it's expired it's hard to renew again most of people will be on student visa. In the Covid Pandemic lot of people lost their times and job for renewing skill assessment through TRA you need 3 years of full time experience or have to do Job ready program again and which is not possible to do on student visa when you already used your 485 visa.

We therefore ask the House to please remove this expiry thing from the skill assessments or just make some easy step to renew skill assessment like they can give a test to the examiner related to their occupation and skill so they can charge a fee for it and renew people skill assessments.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5055)
Health Care

Mental Health Medications cause drowsiness and strokes. An average dosage with have an adult 2-4hours resting without alertness. They are over prescribed and new vogue employment. The area of mental health includes negligence in other areas—health knowledge, finances and social support.

We therefore ask the House to consolidate with the Medical Governance of Australia to make Mental Health Medications illegal. The professions can select to support mental health using their education skills.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN5057)
Taxation: Unions

WH ARE UNIONS N AUSTRALIA NOT PAYING TAX AS ALL OTHER BUSINESSES OR WORKERS UN AUSTRALIA YET THEY ALOWED TO DONATE LIMITLESS AMOUNTOF MONEY TO ONE PARTY & THAT IS LABOR & MOST OFESNISE IS THT TAX PAYERS ARE THEN PAYING FOR UNION MEMETERS A AX DEDUCTION BUT A WORKER IS NOT ALLOWED TO HAVE THEOR CAR GOING TO WORK TO BE A TAX DEDUCTION
We therefore ask the House to MAKE ALL AUSTRALIAN UNIONS PAY THEIR DUE TAX AS ALL OTHER BUSINESSES & WORKERS OF AUSTRALIA
ALL TAX DEDUCTIONS TO UNION MEMEBERS MUST BE REMOVED NOW!
WHY IS IT A TAX DEDUCTION BUT A CAR USED TO GO TO WORK IS NOT A TAX DEDUCTION?
THIS IS INEQUALITY & TAX EVASION
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN5058)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

p.span: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice
TO HAVE A RACIST VOISE IN OUR CONSTITUTION?

TO HAVE ONE RACE ABOVE ALL OTHER RACES OF AUSTRALIAN CITIZANS INSHRINE IN OUR CONSTUTION & MOST OFFENSICE/DISPICABLE OF OUR GOVEREMENTS ALLOWING INEQUALITY &UNELECTED BEUARACRY OF ONLY ONE RACE THAT IS ABORIGINALS/TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS TO HAVE MORE RIGHTRS THEN ALL OTHER RACES OF AUSTRALIAN CITIZANS
We therefore ask the House to STOP THE ALBANESE GOVENRMENT SPENDING OUR HARD ENARED TAX PAYERS MONEY ON A APERHTIED REFERNDUM!
TO MAKE ONE RACE OF AUSTRALIANS (ie ABORIGINALS/TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS) ABOVE ALL OTHER RACES OF AUSTRALIANS TO BE RECOGNISED IN OUR SUPPOSEDLY DEMOCRATECYL ELECTED MEMEBERS IN PARLIAMENT
THIS IS SO OFFENSIVE & DESCRIMINSTORY TO ALL IMMIGRANTS TO THIS COUNTRY

SLL ABORIGINALS/TORRES STRIAT HAVE A VOICE NOW IN OUR PARLIAMENT ie ELECTED MEMEBERS" ? SO ALL OTHER RACES NOT BE RECOGNIZED N OUR AUSTRALIAN COSNTITUITION IS AGAINST EQUALITY THAT AUSTRALIAN SIGNED TO THE UNITED NATIONS
SO THIS WILL BE DESCRIMINATION AGAINST UNITED NATIONS RACIST AGENDA & INEQUALITY!
WE ARE ALL EQUALIT IN AUSTRALIA & NO VOICE & NO WADTE OF OUR TAX PAYERS MONEY WHEN WE HAVE SO MANY MORE IMPORTANT ISSUES AS ENEREGY CRISIS, COST ODF LIVING CRISIS, ect.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN5059)
Bureau of Meteorology

B.O.M. IS NOW USING TWO METHODS OF TEMPATURE MEASURMENETS IN AUSTRALIA & IS NOT USING THE ACTUAL THERMOMETER TEMAPTURES & IS NOT ALLOWING THE CORREECT PUBLISHING LONG TIME DATA OF TEMATURES ALL OVER AUSTRALIA!

We therefore ask the House to MAKE B.O.M. ACCOUNTABLE FOR ACCURATE TEMAPTURE ACCOUNTABLE B.O.M. DATA TO BE MADE YEARLY TO THE AUSTRALIAN TAX PAYERS (ONLINE/PUBLISHED) MEASURED OVER LONG TIME COLLECTED ACCURATE TEMPATURES ALL OVER AUSTRALIA (ie OVER 30 YEARS NOT JUST MERALLY 1 YEAR READING & NOT PUBLISHED DATA OF THE TWO METHODS B.O.M. USES)
WE DEMAND SCIENTIFIC DATA MEASURED TEMATURES AUSTRALIAN WIDE ACCURATE & BY CALIBRATED THERMOMETERS
WE DEAMDN ACCURACY
from 37 citizens (Petition No. EN5060)
North Atlantic Treaty Organization
Australia is facing security challenges in our region as well as, potentially, mainland Europe.
The current aggression in Europe places the European mainland at risk of an overflow into NATO countries.
In addition, the potential aggressive activities by dictatorships towards countries in the Pacific also has the potential to escalate.

The Prime Minister, by attending the summit, would be able to discuss, on several levels, the security of Australia in the event of any aggression overflows into Nato countries and/or aggression in our region such as the current harassment to Taiwan.
We therefore ask the House to require the Prime Minister attend the NATO Summit in July 2023.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5061)
Fuel

During a time of significant low worldwide oil prices currently, there has extreme rise in petrol prices to levels that resemble price gouging, that contributes to a higher level of inflation and standard of living.
We therefore ask the House to establish a royal commission into petrol pricing in Australia.
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN5062)

subdebateinfo.title: Central West New South Wales: Floods

p.span: Central West New South Wales: Floods

In November 2022, the towns of Molong, Eugowra, Canowindra, and Cudal within the shire of Cabonne, Central West, New South Wales were hit with devastating floods resulting in the loss of lives, homes, businesses, infrastructure, and resources.

These areas are vulnerable to flooding in the cases of severe weather events and therefore funding and resources for sustainable flood mitigation are urgently required to better protect these areas from Cabonne from future flooding.

We therefore ask the House to consider legislating a resilience package including a federal home buyback scheme for affected Cabonne residents. As well as necessary funding and resources for flood mitigation to better protect against future flooding events.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN5065)
Defence Procurement: Submarines
Nuclear Pollution is more a risk at sea especially in submarines.
Australia cannot afford it.
Extends the nuclear arms race to Australia
Is an affront to the Peoples Republic of China
Pointless as our conventional submarines are more useful.
We therefore ask the House to ban the use by Australia of nuclear powered vessels till after 2075.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN5066)
Cost of Living
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully request an urgent inquiry into the ongoing cost of living crisis in our country.

The rising cost of housing, food, energy, and other essential goods and services has made it increasingly difficult for many Australians to make ends meet. This has led to widespread financial stress, with families struggling to pay bills, put food on the table, and maintain a decent standard of living.
We believe that this crisis is having a devastating impact on individuals, families, and communities across Australia, and that urgent action is needed to address it.
We therefore ask the House to prehensive inquiry into the cost of living crisis, with the following objectives:
1. To identify the underlying causes of the cost of living crisis, including factors such as inflation, wage stagnation, price gouging and the high cost of housing and energy.
2. To examine the impact of the cost of living crisis on different sectors of the Australian population, including low-income earners, pensioners, and families with young children.
3. To make recommendations for policy measures that can address the cost of living crisis and alleviate the financial burden on Australians.
from 54 citizens (Petition No. EN5068)
Member for Dickson

In 2019 petition EN0963 asked parliament to determine the eligibility of Mr Dutton to sit because of his child care centres receiving tens of millions in Commonwealth funding. EN4465 was refused to be put to parliament for being similar to EN0963. EN0963 related to the 2019 election, EN4465 to the 2022 election. Two totally different events.

The 2019 petition was answered by Mr Porter (AG) saying the Solicitor General stated : Mr Dutton is "not incapable" of sitting as a member of parliament," Mr Porter left out the rest of the Solicitor General's statement in that " there is still "some risk" the high court might find he has a conflict of interest."

There is still some risk Mr Dutton has a conflict of interest and is in breach of S44 of the constitution. The only place that can be determined is at the High Court, not in parliament and not on a register written by the politician.

We therefore ask the House to refer Mr Dutton to the High Court to assess if he is ineligible to nominate for election because of the indirect pecuniary interest of his wife and children getting millions in Commonwealth funding for their child care centres. The Solicitor General's reasoning from 2018 can be used because there is still "some risk" he has a conflict of interest."
There is also the criminal act of fraud for signing a false declaration to nominate to be considered.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN5069)
First Nations Australians
- since 2016 the First Nations caucus committee have not provided the total cost on the taxpayer with closing the gap or got to the heart of First Nations issues
-Since 2018 the Joint Selected Committee have cost the taxpayer millions
-failure since 2019 to enhance local and regional decision-making and options to provide a voice for Indigenous Australians to government'.
-The Australian people demand to know where The 2022-23 Budget provided $31.8 million under the Indigenous Voice—Local and Regional Voice Implementation where this money has gone.
We therefore ask the House to look at the taxpayer and say no to further debts that will incur from this process
from 152 citizens (Petition No. EN5070)
Flags
A Local Council in NSW has decided to fly flags of foreign nations from government buildings, including on April 26th 2023—the day after ANZAC Day.

One of the nations whose flag will be flown is an Apartheid state, as declared by Amnesty International, and continues to dispossess indigenous populations, in on-going violation of international law and blatant disregard for human rights.
Flying their flag from Australian Government buildings shows support for this.
This is an affront to our Australian society.

Our Australian values of peace, respect and inclusivity are not aligned with the foreign nation's values of discrimination and aggression. In our respectful multicultural society, the flying of this foreign nation's flag from government buildings is, firstly, disrespectful around the time of ANZAC Day, our National public holiday, and secondly is traumatising for many Australians who have been disposessed by, or lost loved ones to, the foreign nation.
Australian Government buildings and flagpoles should only fly our national flags, at any time in the year.

We therefore ask the House to legislate that only flags of Australia, including flags of its States and Territories, and inclusive of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags, as per Section 5 of the Flags Act (1953) be flown from public buildings and government-owned flagpoles in Australia, effectively banning the flying of flags of foreign nations from these public structures.
from 35 citizens (Petition No. EN5071)
Eating Disorders

There isn't enough help for carers , and their children that are experiencing an Eating disorder. This disorder has the highest rate of death amongst mental health. Eating disorders are rapidly increasing whilst we have social media that targets children and adolescents . The help in public hospitals aren't enough, no beds, basic care and information re treating the eating disorder and the co- morbidities.Children are taking their lives.

We therefore ask the House to acknowledge there is a little to no science based evidence on how to stop eating disorders in children and adolescents . There are not enough inpatient residents for eating disorders.
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN5075)
Electronic Petitions

There are a huge number of petitions put up by the same individuals who have an axe to grind, often with extremist views and who obviously nothing better to do with their time. I believe this results in a massive waste of taxpayer dollars through reviewing and responding to tedious petitions from vexatious individuals. There are over 25 million people in this country and individuals with single digit support are wasting precious resources on constant complaints about vapid garbage. I believe the parliament should reserve a right to ignore constant submissions from the same serial posters in the interests of efficiency. These are our tax dollars that are being wasted because certain people have nothing better to do. Not every post is worthy of a response.
We therefore ask the House to ignore E petitions from serial complainents
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5076)
Taxation

from 6,556 citizens (Petition No. PN0563)
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 42 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Superannuation
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3932 to the former Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy on the taxation laws relating to Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) insurance payments in superannuation. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Superannuation benefits can generally only be accessed tax free by people who reach age 60 and retire, reflecting the nature of superannuation as a concessionally taxed form of savings designed to provide income in retirement. Whilst concessional treatment is provided to all superannuation benefits, additional special rules apply to TPD payments withdrawn where they are also classified as disability benefits.

Disability benefit payments made as superannuation income streams before a person's preservation age attract a 15 per cent taxation offset to reduce the normal personal marginal tax rate. Such payments made as superannuation lump sums can have their tax-free component increased to reflect the proportion of the total service period that remains unused because of the disability, recognising the period the recipient could have expected to be employed if the disability had not occurred.

Where a person has more than one superannuation account and decides voluntarily to consolidate those accounts, the calculation of the tax-free component for disability benefits uses the earlier total service period of all accounts, and this can result in a lower increase in that component. In addition, as with all merged superannuation accounts, the taxation components are aggregated in the remaining account and these new proportions are used in calculating the components that apply for benefit payment taxation purposes.

These outcomes can also occur if a person's superannuation accounts are consolidated under measures implemented by the Treasury Laws Amendment (Protecting Your Superannuation Package) Act 2019. This included the transfer of accounts with balances below $6,000 which have not received a contribution or rollover for 16 months to the ATO to protect that account from further erosion by fees and charges. The ATO then proactively reunites that inactive, low balance superannuation account with an individual's active account where possible or makes payments directly to the individual if they are over 65 years of age.

Whilst I acknowledge these events can lead to less favourable taxation outcomes in certain circumstances, these policy settings are intended to guard against the undue erosion of superannuation balances through excessive fees and inappropriate insurance arrangements.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Member for Cook
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 referring to me for response, petition EN4361 relating to the Member for Cook, Mr Scott Morrison MP. The petition asks the House to 'put Mr Morrison to the High Court to determine if he can be removed from parliament for being a citizen of New Zealand and to consider pressing criminal charges for signing a false declaration to nominate'.

The House adopted a resolution on 4 April 2019 concerning Members' qualifications with respect to sections 44 and 45 of the Constitution. Relevantly, section 44 of the Constitution provides for disqualification of a person to sit as a Senator or Member for certain reasons, including citizenship of a foreign power. The resolution, titled 'Members' qualifications' is available on the Parliament's website at the following address:
https://www.aph.gov.au/About Parliament/House of Representatives/Powers practice and procedure/resolutions

In addition to requiring Members to provide statements and supplementary material regarding their qualification under the Constitution, the resolution sets out a process by which the House may deal with any question concerning a Member's qualification. The process provides for a Member to refer certain circumstances to the Speaker, and for the Speaker to report the matter to the House. A motion may then be moved to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges and Members' Interests for inquiry and report. The Committee may recommend that the matter be referred to the Court of Disputed Returns under section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, and such a referral would then be subject to a decision of the House.

Importantly, the resolution provides that any question concerning a Member's qualification under the Constitution may be dealt with only in accordance with these procedures, and not otherwise. It also provides that any false statements or omissions under the resolution may be regarded as a serious contempt of the House. However, these are internal processes of the House, limited by the terms of the resolution. Consideration of any criminal charges in relation to false or misleading information in a nomination for election to the House of Representatives would be a matter for the Australian Electoral Commission and the Australian Federal Police.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention and I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Dick
Parliament
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter seeking a response to petition EN4367 relating to the prayers read at the commencement of each sitting of the House of Representatives.

The obligation for the Speaker to say prayers each day as well as the form of the prayers themselves, are set out in the standing orders. The standing orders are a matter for the House as a whole, and it is not within the power of the Speaker to make changes.
Changes to the standing orders have arisen in response to inquiries and recommendation made by the Procedure Committee and its predecessor, the Standing Orders Committee.

In 1972 the Standing Orders Committee considered a submission from a Member which suggested a different form of prayer, and that prayers once a week would suffice. The committee agreed that there should be no change either in the frequency of offering prayers or in their content. When the Procedure Committee reviewed the standing orders in 2002-2003, partly with a view to modernising the language, the committee made no recommendation in relation to the prayers and the revised standing orders adopted in 2004 retained the original wording.
Thank you for writing to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Dick
New South Wales: Flood Mitigation
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, concerning EN4377 calling for a review to identify a plan to mitigate major floods in the New South Wales area. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for the Environment and Water, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Australian Government invests in nationally significant water infrastructure through the National Water Grid Fund. The Government is also investing in disaster resilience, including through the Disaster Ready Fund and Emergency Response Fund.

Notwithstanding the Australian Government's role as a significant investor in water infrastructure, the New South Wales Government is responsible for regional water planning, as well as the construction, operation, and regulation of water infrastructure assets in New South Wales.

Last month, the New South Wales Government decided not to proceed with raising the Warragamba Dam wall and will instead build levies and improve evacuation routes and emergency communications in the Hawkesbury-Nepean.
The Australian Government will work closely with the New South Wales Government to develop flood mitigation solutions across the state.

I thank the Committee for bringing this matter to the Australian Government's attention. I apologise my response falls outside the 90-day response timeframe as there was a delay in the transfer of this petition.
cc: Minister for Emergency Management, Senator the Hon Murray Watt
Minister for Home Affairs, The Hon Clare O'Neil MP
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Health Care
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition number: EN4629, calling for a national Public Inquiry into Australian Government handling of future health pandemics. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Australia has well established arrangements in place to respond quickly and effectively to a range of health emergencies. These arrangements are set out in health sector emergency management plans, which are designed to integrate with broader national emergency plans, particularly the Government Crisis Management Framework.

Australia has world-class public health systems, and we are well-prepared to respond to communicable disease challenges. Australia works closely with the World Health Organisation to ensure that it aligns with One Health activities across the suite of pandemic prevention, preparedness and response as part of its obligations under the International Health Regulations.

The Government response to the COVID-19 pandemic continues to be informed by leading experts, including the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation. Comprised of all state and territory Chief Health Officers and chaired by the Australian Chief Medical Officer, the AHPPC works with state and territory health departments to develop and adopt national health protection policies, guidelines, standards and seek alignment of plans.

On 30 June 2022, the Government commissioned an independent review of Australia's COVID-19 vaccine and treatment procurements. In September 2022, the review, led by Professor Jane Halton AO, handed down eight recommendations. The Government responded to the review in February 2023, accepting seven of the eight recommendations in full. The remaining recommendation, relating to the National Medical Stockpile, was partially accepted noting it was largely outside the terms of reference for the review.

The Prime Minister, the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, has indicated the Government will undertake, at an appropriate future time, an inquiry into Australia's COVID-19 response that will examine the impact of the pandemic and the respective actions of governments. I also note all states and territories, except the Northern Territory, have conducted, or are in the process of conducting, parliamentary inquiries into their COVID-19 responses. The timing of any National Inquiry must be well considered, noting Australia is still experiencing COVID-19, with heightened risk during winter months.

The Government has provided $3.2 million for preparatory work to establish an Australian Centre for Disease Control (CDC) which will enhance Australia's ongoing response and preparedness for current and emerging public health emergencies. Once established, the CDC will ensure ongoing pandemic preparedness, lead the federal response to future disease outbreaks, and work to prevent both non-communicable (chronic) and communicable (infectious) diseases.

Following completion of a targeted consultation process in late 2022, stakeholder feedback is currently being used to inform the Department of Health and Aged Care's advice to Government on the proposed CDC model, including its scope and remit. A staged rollout of the CDC is planned to commence in early 2024.
Additional information on the establishment of the Australian CDC, including a summary of consultation feedback, is available on the department's website at www.health.gov.au/our-work/Australian-CDC.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Housing
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for referring a copy of the petition (Petition Ministerial Referral EN 4633) to me and bringing this matter to my attention.

The petition 'asks the House to create a Volume 4 to the NCC (National Construction Code) that relates Solely to the Social Housing'. However, the provision of social housing, including its appearance and density, is a matter for state and territory governments through their respective planning and development control systems.

The NCC sets the minimum technical requirements for building safety, health, amenity, accessibility and sustainability, and is given legal effect through each state and territory's building regulations. The NCC does not differentiate between housing which is privately or publicly funded.

The Albanese Government understands access to secure and affordable housing has significant social, economic and personal benefits, and has committed to implementing a number of initiatives to help Australian households access safe and affordable housing. These initiatives include:
The expansion of the remit of the National Housing Infrastructure Facility to more flexibly deploy up to $575 million to accelerate the supply of social and affordable housing.
The Housing Australia Future Fund to help build 30,000 new social and affordable housing prope1iies in its first five years and create thousands of jobs.

A National Housing Supply and Affordability Council to independently advise the Government on housing policy, particularly advice on options to improve housing supply and affordability. The Government has established an interim Council which commenced on 1 January 2023 as a non-statutory body. It is intended a permanent Council will commence following the passage of legislation.
A National Housing and Homelessness Plan to establish a clear national strategy to address the significant challenges facing the housing and homelessness sector.

The National Housing and Homelessness Plan will be developed in collaboration with key stakeholders. This includes state and territory governments, local government, not-for-profit and civil society organisations, industry bodies, superannuation funds and other experts in housing, finance and urban development.

The National Housing and Homelessness Plan will be informed by advice from the newly established National Housing Supply and Affordability Council and will set out the key short-, medium- and long-term reforms needed to improve housing and homelessness outcomes across Australia.

If the petitioner would like to receive updates on consultation opportunities and receive information about the progress of the Plan, they can subscribe for updates at www.engage.dss.gov.au/developing-the-national-housing-and-homelessness-plan/.
Thank you again for bringing the concerns raised in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Industry and Science, Mr Husic
Conduct of Elections
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for referring petition EN4658 about the examination of federal elections and compulsory voting. I respond as the Special Minister of State, responsible for electoral matters.

The Labor Party has led legislation for federal electoral reform in Australia. Reforms by the Hawke Government in the 1980s provided the framework for Australia's contemporary elections and our democracy. Importantly, that Government transformed our democratic institutions with the creation of the independent Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) to conduct and oversee elections.

This petition requests an inquiry into elections, particularly in relation to the integrity of elections. The Government is committed to strengthening the integrity of our electoral system and considers voter confidence and scrutiny entitlements in election processes imperative to the functioning of our democracy.

The count process is detailed, with the scrutiny held over a number of weeks. This is to ensure that Australians can have confidence in the outcome of elections. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Electoral Act) and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 (Referendum Act) contain legislative safeguards to support the integrity of the Australian electoral system, including processes for checks and balances on the scrutiny, which involves the AEC conducting an initial sorting of pre-poll votes, scrutiny on voting night and fresh scrutiny. The progress of these scrutinies is progressively published on the AEC Tally Room, which is available online at https://results.aec.gov.au/27966/Website/HouseDefault-27966.htm.

Protecting the integrity of Australia's electoral processes is critical to maintaining public trust in Australia's democratic processes. The Electoral Integrity Assurance Taskforce (EIAT) was established for the 2022 Federal Election to provide information and advice to the Electoral Commissioner on matters that may compromise the real or perceived integrity of the federal election. The EIAT is made up of relevant agencies across federal government working together within their own remits. More information on the EIAT is available at: https://www.aec.gov.au/about_aec/electoral-integrity.htm.

Additionally, ahead of the 2022 Federal Election, the AEC re-established their 'Stop and Consider Campaign', which builds on the success of a similar campaign run at the 2019 federal election that aims to help voters cut through mis- and disinformation. The AEC also established a disinformation register that lists prominent pieces of disinformation regarding the election process, detailing when the communication was brought to the AEC's attention and actions taken.

On 5 August 2022, I wrote to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM) asking that they inquire into all aspects of the 2022 federal election. JSCEM will consider the integrity of the federal electoral system and any matters concerning the integrity of the 2022 federal election. I am looking forward to receiving the Committee's report about its investigations, and its recommendations. On receipt I will be engaging with parliamentarians and others who operate in our electoral system to seek their views on proposed electoral reform. Information about the inquiry, including its Terms of Reference, are available at:
https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral Matters.

Additionally, the petition requests the abolition of compulsory voting. Compulsory voting is the cornerstone of Australian democracy. As you would be aware, the Electoral Act and the Referendum Act require all eligible Australian citizens to enrol and vote at each election and referendum. Compulsory voting has been part of Australian federal elections since 1924. The Government supports compulsory voting as it strengthens our democratic process and ensures that the vast majority of citizens actively participate in elections.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Senator Farrell
COVID-19: Response
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding petition number EN4670 calling for a Commonwealth Royal Commission into the COVID-19 Pandemic response in Australia and an Australian Human Rights Commission inquiry into the violation of human rights on a federal, territory and state basis.

Australia has well established arrangements in place to respond quickly and effectively to a range of health emergencies. These arrangements are set out in health sector emergency management plans, which are designed to integrate with broader national emergency plans, particularly the Australian Government Crisis Management Framework.

Australia has world-class public health systems, and we are well-prepared to respond to communicable disease challenges. Australia works closely with the World Health Organization to ensure that it aligns with One Health activities across the suite of pandemic prevention, preparedness and response as part of its obligations under the International Health Regulations.

The Australian Government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic continues to be informed by leading experts, including the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation. Comprised of all state and territory Chief Health Officers and chaired by the Australian Chief Medical Officer, the AHPPC works with state and territory health departments to develop and adopt national health protection policies, guidelines, standards and seek alignment of plans.

On 30 June 2022, the Government commissioned an independent review of Australia's COVID-19 vaccine and treatment procurements. In September 2022, the review, led by Professor Jane Halton AO, handed down eight recommendations. The Government responded to the review in February 2023, accepting seven of the eight recommendations in full. The remaining recommendation, relating to the National Medical Stockpile, was partially accepted noting it was largely outside the terms of reference for the review.

The Prime Minister, the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, has indicated the Government will undertake, at an appropriate future time, an inquiry into Australia's COVID-19 response that will examine the impact of the pandemic and the respective actions of governments. I also note all states and territories, except the Northern Territory, have conducted, or are in the process of conducting, parliamentary inquiries into their COVID-19 responses.
The timing of any national inquiry must be well considered, noting Australia is still experiencing COVID-19, with heightened risk during winter months.

The Government has provided $3.2 million for preparatory work to establish an Australian Centre for Disease Control (CDC) which will enhance Australia's ongoing response and preparedness for current and emerging public health emergencies. Once established, the CDC will ensure ongoing pandemic preparedness, lead the federal response to future disease outbreaks, and work to prevent both non-communicable (chronic) and communicable (infectious) diseases. Following completion of a targeted consultation process in late 2022, stakeholder feedback is currently being used to inform the Department of Health and Aged Care's advice to Government on the proposed CDC model, including its scope and remit. A staged rollout of the CDC is planned to commence in early 2024.
Additional information on the establishment of the Australian CDC, including a summary of consultation feedback, is available on the department's website at www.health.gov.au/our-work/Australian-CDC.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4709, with 19 signatures, concerning government services eligibility and residential property acquisition for Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) (subclass 491) visa and Skilled Employer Sponsored Regional (Provisional) (subclass 494) visa holders.
The Australian Government recognises the important role Skilled Regional Provisional visa holders play in supporting regional economies, employers and communities.

Holders of subclass 491 and subclass 494 visas are able to apply for the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa in the Regional Provisional stream after three years, provided they meet the eligibility criteria for that visa (including having complied with the conditions of their skilled regional visa). Once granted, this visa would provide access to government payments, services and benefits available to Australian permanent residents, subject to any waiting periods that may apply.

Skilled Regional Provisional visa holders as temporary residents may seek to acquire an interest in residential land; however, the specific proposals raised in the petition are complex matters. Independent legal advice should be sought before applying for foreign investment approval. Information about foreign investment in residential land, including details about the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) application fees and fee waivers is available from the FIRB and Australian Tax Office (ATO) websites at:
FIRB: https://firb.gov.au/land-investments; and
ATO: https://www.ato.gov.au/General/Foreign-investment-in-Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4709 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Permanent Residence Visas
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you or your correspondence of 6 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4718, with one signature, seeking the provision of permanent residency to international students who studied onshore during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The primary purpose of the Student visa program is to facilitate the arrival of international students to live and study in Australia temporarily, in order to obtain a high quality education. There is no pathway to permanent residence for international students. Following their studies, however, Student visa holders may seek to apply for a further stay in Australia, either temporarily or permanently, subject to meeting eligibility criteria.

The Skilled visa program recognises the value of an Australian education. International students who have completed a bachelor's degree or higher, a diploma, an advanced diploma, or a trade qualification undertaken at an Australian educational institution are awarded additional points towards meeting the criteria for certain permanent Skilled visas. Further information on these visa options are available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-finder.

The Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa (TGV) provides recently graduated international students the opportunity to live and work in Australia following completion of their studies. This visa allows recently graduated students to gain temporary access to the Australian labour market, and obtain practical work experience to accompany their qualification.
I am pleased to advise that on 21 February 2022, the Ministers for Education and Home Affairs jointly announced the extension of TGV Post Study Work Rights.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4718 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Bali Nine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for referring petition EN4721 to me in relation to the remaining five incarcerated members of the group known as the 'Bali Nine'.
I appreciate the continued concern and depth of community sentiment for the men and agree they deserve the opportunity to have their life sentences reduced to fixed terms and returned to Australia.

While I am not able to provide details on the men's cases due to my obligations under the Privacy Act 1988, please be assured that the Australian Government is doing all it can to assist the men and their families, including advocating for their early return.

These cases remain a high priority for me and the government, and the Indonesian Government is aware of our position. We will continue to support the applications of the Australian men for sentence conversion at the highest levels.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Medicare
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN4729 requesting increases to the Medicare rebate. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I note the Petition signees' request to increase the Medicare rebate to encourage appropriate remuneration for GPs and to encourage bulk billing. Strengthening Medicare is a top priority for the Australian Government. On 3 February 2023, I was pleased to release the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce (Taskforce) report, developed by primary health care leaders and experts in their fields. The report supports the Government's vision for a stronger Medicare, designed and funded for the 21st cent1,1ry. In addition to the $2.9 billion investment we made in primary care in the 2022-23 October Budget, the Government has committed $750 million to the Strengthening Medicare Fund, which will be the next stage of the major revamp of the primary care system.
The vision for a stronger Medicare is one that:
gives all Australians access to equitable, affordable care services that place patients at the centre
empowers coordinated multidisciplinary teams of health care professionals, working to their full scope of practice to achieve excellent patient outcomes
better uses data and digital technology to give patients greater involvement in their care and to meet expectations for integrated and seamless health systems
supports the primary care sector to embrace organisational and cultural change so that patients and practitioners alike can be part of creating a better health system for all Australians.

Patient-centred care is central to the recommendations of the report, supported by an expansion of multidisciplinary care as the key to managing the health of an older population with more complex and chronic disease. The report recommends supporting this with new blended funding models, integrated with the existing fee-for-service model, allowing teams of GPs, nurses, midwives, and allied health professionals to work together to deliver the care people need. The Taskforce noted that by introducing funding reforms that better reward providers for providing quality, person-centred models of care, we can also position primary care as a career of choice for health professionals, including medical, allied health, nursing and midwifery graduates.
We will bring forward our plan to deliver on the highest priority investments guided by the Taskforce's recommendations through the 2023-24 Budget. The report is available at
www.health.gov.au/resources/publications/strengthening-medicare-taskforce-report.

While the Government is responsible for setting Medicare fees and rebates, GPs operate their practices as private businesses and are free to determine whether they bulk bill some or all of their patients or charge a co-payment. Nonetheless, the Government remains committed to ensuring Australians can access high quality and affordable health care and supports both free and subsidised health care services. This includes providing Medicare benefits (rebates) for privately rendered services listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) and free hospital services for public patients in public hospitals. Any changes to the MBS will be considered through the 2023-24 Budget and future Budget processes.

The Government provides a bulk billing incentive for bulk billed services for patients with a Commonwealth Concession Card and children under 16 years of age. In addition, the Government invests in Rural Bulk Billing Incentives (RBBI) that pay higher benefits to regional, rural and remote doctors for bulk billing. More information about the RBBI is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care1s website at
www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/rural-bulk-billing-incentives.

The Government recognises that unforeseen out-of-pocket expenses can add to the distress of those who suffer serious or unexpected illnesses and provides assurance to patients who incur high out-of-pocket medical expenses through both the Original Medicare Safety Net and the Extended Medicare Safety Net. Where possible, patients are also encouraged to select an appropriate health provider based on their health care and financial needs.
Information about medical practices offering bulk billed services can be found using the 'services finder' on the healthdirect website at www.healthdirect.gov.au.

The Government supports the development of the GP workforce through fully funded training programs, including the Australian General Practice Training (AGPT) program. The AGPT program has a yearly intake of 1,500 training places and provides registrars with medical education and training placements to support their learning towards GP fellowship. As part of the AGPT program, support payments are provided to registrars, supervisors and practices. The AGPT program is delivered by both the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the Australian College of Rural and Remote Medicine. The department is continuing to work closely with the colleges on GP attraction strategies.

The Government recognises that bringing the employment conditions for GP registrars into closer alignment with those of hospital-based registrars could have a positive impact on the career choices of doctors in training. Following the October 2022 Budget announcement to establish 10 new Single Employer Model trials, I wrote to each of my state and Northern Territory counterparts to invite them to establish single employer model trials in their state.

The Government is also progressing a project that is exploring the options for a portability scheme for GP registrars' employment entitlements. A portability scheme would allow GP registrars to transfer and retain employment entitlements as they rotate through GP practices during training.

The National Medical Workforce Strategy 2021-2031 was developed to guide long-term collaborative medical workforce planning across Australia. It identifies achievable, practical actions to build a sustainable, highly trained medical workforce. This includes actions to attract medical students and doctors in raining into career pathways of specialties in undersupply, including general practice; rebalance the number of trainees in oversupplied specialties; and support workforce retention.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4780, with 182 signatures, concerning the processing times of the Skilled Work Regional (subclass 491) provisional visa.

The Australian Government recognises the important and valuable contribution skilled regional visa holders, including subclass 491 visa holders, have made in closing labour and skills gaps and supporting businesses and communities particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic through their commitment to living, working and studying in regional areas of Australia.

The Australian Government is committed to clearing visa backlogs. Strong progress has been made. As announced at the Jobs and Skills Summit on 1 and 2 September 2022, a one-off investment of $36.1 million has been made by the Government to fund an extra 500 positions to support temporary and migration visa processing undertaken by the Department of Home Affairs to reduce on hand visa applications, including in the subclass 491 caseload. We have finalised 5.42 million temporary and migration visa applications since 1 July 2022.

There is more work to do to further reduce processing times. As the Department continues to uplift staff capacity and capability, implement new policy settings and streamline processes, processing times will trend down.

Skilled visa applications are processed according to Government policy priorities, which are outlined in Ministerial Direction No. 100 and commenced in October 2022. More information is available from the Department's website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-processing-times/skilled-visa-processing-priorities.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4780 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
HomeBuilder Grant
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the former Treasurer, the Hon Josh Frydenberg MP, concerning Petition EN3294 on extending the HomeBuilder application deadline. As the petition was not addressed by the previous Government, your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
HomeBuilder is administered under the National Partnership Agreement on HomeBuilder (NPA), agreed to by the former Government and state and territory governments.

The NPA outlines the application eligibility criteria for HomeBuilder. In administering HomeBuilder on behalf of the Commonwealth, states and territories determine the evidentiary requirements to satisfy themselves that an applicant has met the criteria. The definition and assessment of an eligible contract is in the remit of each jurisdiction.

On 29 November 2020, the former Government announced that the HomeBuilder program would be extended to include eligible contracts signed between 1 January 2021 and 31 March 2021. As part of this extension, a revised NPA was agreed which provided that applications must be submitted by 14 April 2021.
The states and territories have sole discretion to determine whether an application has been validly submitted by the deadline.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Parliamentary Standards
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence referring petition EN4099 on reforms to Australia's electoral environment and government accountability.

As the petition raised many issues across different areas of government, I have sought input from various portfolios to provide this response to the petitioner. I acknowledge this response has taken longer than anticipated to provide due to the breadth of matters traversed and the ongoing work and progress of the Government.

span.span: Item 1: Implementation of Uluru Statement from the Heart

p.span: The Government is committed to implementing the Uluru Statement from the Heart in full. This includes holding a referendum to recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the Constitution through a Voice and establishing the Makarrata Commission that will oversee a national process of treaty making and truth telling.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring integrity and accountability in the federal government by establishing a powerful, transparent and independent National Anti-Corruption Commission. On 30 November 2022, legislation to establish the Commission was passed by the Australian Parliament. The Government intends the Commission will be operational by mid-2023 and has committed $262.6 million over four years to support the establishment and ongoing operation of the Commission.

The Commission will form a central pillar of the Government's agenda to restore integrity and confidence in the federal public sector by ensuring there is an agency with a dedicated focus on detecting and investigating serious or systemic corruption. The Commission will operate independently of Government and have broad jurisdiction to investigate Commonwealth ministers, parliamentarians and their staff, statutory officer holders, employees and contractors of all government entities, and any person whose conduct could adversely affect the honest or impartial exercise of a public official's functions. It will have strong powers to investigate serious or systemic conduct, including criminal and non-criminal conduct, and conduct that occurred before its establishment. The Commission will also undertake corruption prevention and education activities to strengthen the Commonwealth's broader integrity framework.

The Australian Government supports a diverse and sustainable media sector. We recognise that quality news and public interest journalism play an important role in the functioning of Australian society and democracy and are essential to informing local communities, particularly in relation to national and global events.

The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 sets out rules regarding the control and diversity of media ownership in Australia. These rules support a diverse media sector by limiting the number of media operations that can be controlled by a person in a licence area. The Australian Communications and Media Authority is responsible for administering these rules.

The Government is implementing further measures that support the long-term viability of the sector. These include a $29 million local news and community broadcasting transition package to support regional, local and community media providers facing immediate challenges.

The Government has also committed to developing a News Media Assistance Program to secure the evidence base needed to inform longer term news media policy interventions and to develop measures to support public interest journalism and media diversity.

The Government has referred consideration of a range of initiatives to improve the transparency of Australia's political donation laws to the Parliament's Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM), including 'real-time' disclosure, a reduction of the disclosure threshold to $1,000, and truth in political advertising laws. Additionally, the Committee will also consider potential reforms to the funding of elections, including electoral expenditure caps and public funding of parties and candidates.

JSCEM has commenced their inquiry into the 2022 Federal Election and the Government will consider any recommendations made by JSCEM following its inquiries. Further information on the Committee and the specific Terms of Reference is available at: www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters.

The ABC is an essential service and is a trusted source of news, information and entertainment for all Australians. In the face of political, social and economic instability at home and abroad, we must ensure that Australia's instruments of nation building, democracy and culture remain strong now and into the future. This includes independent public service media that holds power to account on behalf of the Australian people.

The ABC is government-funded but has operational and editorial independence so that its programs may be free of political and commercial interference. The ABC's independence is enshrined in legislation but the ABC remains accountable through complaints processes, its annual reports, government audits and inquiries, and appearances before Parliament, including Senate Estimates.

It is essential to bolster the independence and stability of the national broadcasters as a guard against political interference in Australia's democratic institutions. This is why the Government has committed to providing the ABC with five-year funding terms, which will increase funding certainty outside the electoral cycle. Increased funding stability will improve the capacity of the national broadcaster to innovate as well as plan ahead with the diverse ecosystems the ABC supports, including across education, screen production and international broadcasting.
The Government has also committed to the reversal of $83.7 million in cuts to the ABC, as well as increased funding for ABC International as part of an Inda-Pacific Broadcasting Strategy.

In addition to better funding for the ABC, the Government will review options for delivering a greater level of financial stability and certainty to the national broadcasters to safeguard against arbitrary ideological cuts and political interference. This review will be informed by the findings of the Senate Environment and Communications References Committee inquiry into allegations of political interference to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

Further, the Government respects the independence of the Australian Electoral Commission and will give it the powers and resources it needs to ensure the integrity of the electoral system. The Government will also ensure that the Australian National Audit Office is appropriately resourced to carry out its important role providing performance audits and other independent oversight of Australian Government expenditure.

The Set the Standard: Report on the Independent Review into Commonwealth Parliamentary Workplaces (Set the Standard Report) sets out a framework for action to ensure that Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces are safe and respectful, uphold the standing of the Parliament and meet community expectations. The 47th Parliament re-established the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Standards to develop Codes of Conduct for Parliamentarians and their staff.

Parliament endorsed the draft Behaviour Standards and Codes (Senate 8 February 2023, House of Representatives 9 February 2023) as presented in the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Standards' report (released on 29 November 2022), pending the establishment of the advisory and enforcement regime, and the final adoption of Behaviour Standards and Codes for parliamentarians, parliamentarians' staff and Commonwealth parliamentary workplaces. The Government is continuing the work in this important area.
Thank you again for bringing the matters referred to in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Senator Farrell
HomeBuilder
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4611—Extend the deadline for submission of documentation for HomeBuilder. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Government understands that matters outside of Australians' control have led to the disruption of the construction industry and supply lines, and as a result has impacted the ability of some existing HomeBuilder applicants to meet the 30 April 2023 deadline for providing supporting documentation.

On 27 April 2023, I announced that I had signed a revised National Partnership Agreement on HomeBuilder (NPA) on behalf of the Commonwealth. The revised NPA extends the deadline for document submission from 30 April 2023 to 30 June 2025.

This extension will only apply to existing applicants who had entered financial commitments on the basis they would receive the grant but, through no fault of their own, were affected by supply constraints and construction industry delays.

This extension will provide sufficient time for all outstanding applicants to complete the eligibility requirements to receive the HomeBuilder grant. The eligibility requirements for the HomeBuilder program will remain the same.
The revised NPA will apply in a state or territory whose government also signs the revised NPA.
Updates on when state and territory governments agree to the revised NPA will be made at the Treasury HomeBuilder website at treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/homebuilder.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email dated 6 March 2023, concerning the petition relating to social welfare payments for cancer patients (EN4653). I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is strongly committed to an income support system that operates as a safety net for people who need it most while ensuring the system remains sustainable for Australian taxpayers. The Disability Support Pension (DSP) is an income support payment available for people who are unable to work at least 15 hours a week due to a physical, intellectual or psychiatric impairment, for at least the next 2 years, and the level of their impairment is such that it attracts at least 20 points under the Tables for the assessment of work- related impairment for Disability Support Pension (the Impairment Tables).

Eligibility for DSP is based on the functional impairment, which results from a person's medical condition, and how this impacts their ability to work, rather than on diagnosis or specific medical conditions alone. People with cancer may be eligible for the DSP, depending on their individual circumstances.

The Impairment Tables are designed to assess a person's loss of functional capacity that affects their ability to work. The Department of Social Services undertook a review of the previous DSP Impairment Tables legislative instrument prior to its expiry on 1 April 2023. The review included extensive public consultation with disability peak bodies, advocacy groups, people with lived experience of the DSP process and medical professionals to gather feedback on the previous Tables.

The new Impairment Tables came into effect on 1 April 2023 and aim to clarify requirements, including that a person's condition must be diagnosed, reasonably treated and stabilised, and the resulting impairment of their condition must, more likely than not, persist for more than 2 years.

As a result of the review, and in consultation with cancer and oncology experts, changes were also made to better represent cancer, by incorporating references to specific types of cancer and their functional impacts as examples of conditions and impairments which may be considered under relevant Tables. Changes were also made to acknowledge the ongoing impacts of side effects from prescribed medication and treatments, such as chemotherapy, by adding overarching guidance stating consideration should be given to an impairment resulting from these treatments when selecting the appropriate Table/s for assessment, and subsequently assessing the impairment.

In certain circumstances a claim for DSP can be granted manifestly. This means that on the basis of medical evidence alone the person is considered eligible for DSP. This may include a person who has a condition that has a life expectancy of less than 2 years (e.g. terminal cancer).

While a condition may not meet these requirements for the resulting impairment to be considered for DSP, this does not mean the condition is not understood to be serious. Some people found ineligible for DSP would be eligible for activity test exemptions under another income support payment, such as JobSeeker Payment, due to the current state of their health.

When a person claiming or receiving the JobSeeker Payment is diagnosed with cancer or another serious illness, the severity of their condition can determine if they are eligible for a serious illness temporary incapacity exemption from mutual obligation requirements. This can be granted for up to 52 weeks, based on the dates indicated on a single medical certificate. Where the same serious illness persists, an additional period of exemption of up to 6 months can be considered based on further medical evidence.

JobSeeker recipients with cancer may also be referred for an Employment Services Assessment to have their work capacity assessed by a health professional.
