If the person is determined to have a Partial Capacity to Work their mutual obligation requirements will be reduced in line with their assessed work capacity.
Thank you for writing to me on this important issue.
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Veterans
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding Parliamentary Petition EN4659, which states:

'I'm a veteran currently receiving a services pension from DVA [the Department of Veterans' Affairs] they have assessed DFRDB [Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits] as Defined Benefit income stream. They applied asset test which has reduced my service pension. The changes in legislation registered 20 Oct 2022 allows for asset-test exemption for defined benefit income stream. DFRDB is a defined benefit income stream DVA uses the term to describe DFRDB. '
Parliamentary Petition EN4659 requests that the House of Representatives (House):

span.span: 'determine that DFRDB is an income stream that is asset-test exempt income stream for the purposes of the [Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA)]. The DFRDB income stream is a defined benefit income stream and has been so from the day the income stream began being paid. I'm requesting DFRDB be recognised as exempt from asset-testing'.

p.span: The petitioner may be referring to the Veterans' Entitlements (Guidelines for Determining Whether Income Stream is Asset-test Exempt) Determination 2022 (Determination), registered on 20 October 2022. Consistent with longstanding practice, section 18 of the Determination allows the Repatriation Commission (Commission) to determine that an income stream is an asset-test exempt income stream for the purposes of the VEA if, relevantly, the Commission is satisfied that 'the income stream is a defined benefit income stream, and has been so from the day the income stream began being paid'.
The Commission has determined that DFRDB is an income stream that is asset-test exempt, on the basis that it is a defined benefit income stream and has been from commencement.

However, defined benefit income streams such as the DFRDB are still subject to the income test under the VEA. The application of the income test can lead to a reduction in the rate of pension payable to a veteran and their partner if applicable, if their income is higher than a prescribed threshold. This is so even though the DFRDB entitlement is not taken into account under the asset-test itself.

In the circumstances, I do not consider it is necessary for the House to take any additional action in response to Parliamentary Petition EN4659, because DFRDB is already considered to be asset-test exempt.
Thank you for taking the time to write. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans Affairs., Mr Keogh
Family Law
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your letter of 14 March 2023 to the Hon Mark Butler MP, Minister for Health and Aged Care, regarding Petition EN4705. As the issues raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities as the Attorney-General, your letter was referred to me for reply.

Petition EN4705 is requesting for publicly funded psychiatric and psychological assessments that have been ordered by the court in family law cases, and for such assessments to be treated as a matter of urgency.

The Family Law Act 1975 enables the family law courts to order expert reports where expert evidence is required to assist in the resolution of proceedings. Expe1i witnesses in family law matters include psychologists, social workers, child and family psychiatrists, medical specialists and treating practitioners. These expe1is may provide evidence to the court on matters within their area of expe1iise. For example, a psychologist or psychiatrist may provide evidence where mental health issues are raised, or an addiction specialist may provide evidence in matters where parental substance misuse is to be considered.

Experts may also provide evidence through a 'family report', which is a professional forensic assessment unde1iaken to assist a court and/or the parties decide on parenting arrangements for children of separated parents or caregivers. It is an independent, professional forensic appraisal of the family, done from a social science perspective. The assessment provides information about the needs of children and their relationships with their parents and other significant adults and the parental capacities of the adults with regard to the children's needs.
The Attorney-General's Department provides Commonwealth legal financial assistance with the cost of legal disbursements in Commonwealth, non-criminal law matters.

The Disbursement Support Scheme can assist people in need who are not able to receive legal aid assistance or assistance under one of the other legal financial assistance schemes. Disbursements are costs associated with legal action, other than the fees paid to be represented by a solicitor or a barrister, for example the cost of expert reports.
Further information on the scheme and how to apply can be found on the department's website:
https://www.ag.gov.au/legal-system/legal-assistance/commonwealth-legal-financial-assistance/disbursement-support-scheme. Complete applications will be assessed within 28 days.

Monetary limits apply to certain disbursements and these are set out in the Commonwealth Legal Financial Assistance Schemes—Assessment of costs (https://www.ag.gov.au/legal-system/publications/commonwealth-legal-financial-assistance-schemes-assessment-costs). A psychiatric report is payable to a maximum of $3,500, inclusive of GST. A psychologist report is payable to a maximum of $2,000, inclusive of GST.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney General, Mark Dreyfus
Child Abuse
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 6 March 2023 regarding Petition EN4736.

Child sexual abuse is an abhorrent and pervasive crime that requires a strong criminal justice response. I appreciate the Petitioner's concerns about the safety and wellbeing of Australia's children. The Australian Government remains committed to protecting children from sexual abuse and ensuring Australia's criminal justice response adequately reflects the profound harm caused to victims and survivors, and to communities.

While states and territories have primary responsibility to legislate on matters related to child sexual abuse within their jurisdiction, the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Cth) includes a world-leading framework of offences relating to child sexual abuse and dealings with child abuse material committed via a carriage service (such as a mobile phone or the Internet), via a postal service, and by Australian citizens and residents while overseas. Under this framework, offenders who commit ce1tain child sexual abuse offences may face up to 30 years' imprisonment. Furthermore, the framework includes mandatory minimum sentences for the most serious child sexual abuse offences and repeat offenders.

The National Office for Child Safety (National Office) was announced as part of the Australian Government Response to the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse, and was established on 1 July 2018. The National Office sits within my Department and provides national leadership, working across governments and sectors, to deliver policies and strategies to enhance children's safety and reduce future harm to children, with a particular focus on child sexual abuse.

On 27 October 2021, the Australian Government launched the National Strategy to Prevent and Respond to Child Sexual Abuse (2021-2030) (National Strategy). The National Strategy is a 10-year, whole-of-nation framework to establish a coordinated and consistent approach to preventing and better responding to child sexual abuse in all settings. The National Strategy is informed by a public health framework, and recognises that everyone—individuals, families, communities, organisations, governments—has a role to play in protecting children and young people, generating cultural change, and empowering and supporting victims and survivors. Implementation of the National Strategy is led by the National Office.
To support its implementation, the Government has invested an initial $307.5 million for the National Strategy's first four years from 2021-22 to 2024-25.
This funding includes over $160 million for offending prevention and intervention measures, including:
$109.8 million allocated to the Australian Federal Police to combat child sexual abuse and exploitation
$24.1 million to enhance the Commonwealth's capacity to prosecute perpetrators of child sexual abuse and bolster government-funded legal assistance for this crime type
$9.6 million to deliver a national child sexual abuse offending prevention service
$2.9 million to strengthen financial intelligence efforts to disrupt the cash flow behind child sexual abuse
$3.8 million to expand intelligence work targeting Australians who pay to watch live-streamed abuse of children overseas
$3 million to bolster digital industry engagement on tackling online child sexual abuse
$4.1 million for the Government to work with Inda-Pacific partners on child sexual abuse.

The Australian Government is also committed to supporting and empowering victims and survivors of child sexual abuse, as well as their families and supporters. The National Strategy includes measures to support victims and survivors of child sexual abuse, including work to:
undertake a scoping study to identify and improve civil remedies for victims of Commonwealth child sexual abuse offences
map available support services responding to child sexual abuse across Australia, and to develop minimum standards for the delivery of those services
set up a single national referral point for victims, survivors and the community to more easily find information and access support
develop guidance for service providers to build their capability to support victims and survivors in a trauma-informed, culturally-safe way, and
set up a national support service for the non-offending friends and family members of child sexual abuse perpetrators.
Thank you again for bringing the Petitioner's concerns to the Government's attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney General, Mark Dreyfus
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 21 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4765, with three signatures, concerning the request to remove section 48 of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) for Student and work visa applicants.

In accordance with s48 of the Act, in certain circumstances, a person who is in Australia, and who does not hold a substantive visa, can validly apply only for certain visas if they have had a substantive visa application refused or a visa cancelled since last arriving in Australia. The limitation on applications under s48 prevents repeat or successive visa applications being made by a person who is trying to delay departure from Australia.

Regulation 2.12 of the Migration Regulations 1994 prescribes the list of visa subclasses to which s48 of the Act does not apply, therefore allowing the person to lodge an application for the visa subclasses listed. This list includes, among others, some Skilled Work visas, some Family visas, Protection visas and Bridging visas; however, it does not include Student visas.
Except in certain circumstances (such as a person who has been removed from Australia), a person who has departed Australia can apply for a Student or work visa to travel to and remain in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4765 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Tick-bite Illnesses
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 March 2023 on behalf of the House of Representative's Standing Committee on Petitions regarding tick-borne illnesses (refer petition number PN0556).
I have responded to the petitioner's specific requests, in detail, below.

span.span: 1) Australians to be allowed to be tested for any Tick-borne infections by GP's or in hospitals, regardless of where or how the infection was acquired; and
2) Australians to be allowed to be treated for any Tick-borne infections for as long or as often as necessary due to the relapsing, remitting nature of some Tick-borne Infections.

p.span: The Australian Government acknowledges that tick-borne illnesses cause considerable morbidity in Australia. These illnesses include Queensland tick typhus, Flinders Island spotted fever, Australian spotted fever and Q fever which are all caused by transmission of rickettsia bacteria by ticks to humans.

While there are no specific Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) items for infection associated with tick bites (this is a feature of MBS—e.g., there are not specific items for infections like Japanese encephalitis which is associated with mosquito bites), items which facilitate consultations are used to diagnose and treat patients with Australian endemic tick-borne diseases. Using clinical judgement and experience, Australian healthcare providers can diagnose and treat Australian endemic tick-borne diseases or provide referrals to specialists for more complex cases.

Tick bite diagnoses are challenging as clinical features can be similar to many other diseases. Consultation with appropriate experts in vector-borne diseases including specialist microbiologists with diagnostic experience and infectious disease physicians for treatment of diagnosed vector-borne diseases is recommended.

Medicare operates with GPs as the gatekeepers for referrals for specialist pathologist and consultant physician services that would include patients with tick-borne illnesses. The MBS items are designed to promote flexibility and responsiveness.

Lyme disease is commonly found in parts of the United Kingdom, the United States of America, and Asia. Visitors to these areas can become infected and return to Australia with Lyme disease. Australian healthcare providers can readily diagnose and treat Lyme disease in patients bitten by a tick in Lyme disease-endemic areas. All confirmed Lyme disease cases to date have been in returned travellers.

However, the bacteria that cause Lyme disease overseas, Borrelia burgdorferi, has not been identified in Australian ticks despite multiple studies that have searched for it. For this reason, the Government does not support the diagnosis of locally acquired Lyme disease. Locally acquired Lyme disease is also not generally accepted by the Australian medical profession.
Australian infectious diseases physicians receive training that includes the management of classical Lyme disease.

In the absence of epidemiological evidence (such as overseas travel to a Lyme endemic area) pointing towards a high pre-test probability, testing for Lyme disease is not generally accepted by the Australian medical profession as necessary for the appropriate management of the patient and therefore not clinically relevant. A confirmed case of Lyme disease in Australia requires laboratory, clinical and epidemiological evidence.

span.span: Patient presenting with persistent debilitating symptoms and no diagnosis

p.span: The Debilitating Symptom Complexes Attributed to Ticks (DSCATT) Clinical Pathway has been developed to support decision-making on differential diagnosis and referral pathways for patients presenting with either new onset or unresolved debilitating symptoms with or without a history of tick bites and that cannot be attributed to another condition (acute or chronic).

For your information, the Department of Health and Aged Care has published a series of educational materials on tick-borne illnesses for the public, as well as for clinicians. These resources, as well as the DSCATT Clinical Pathway are available at www.health.gov.au using the search term 'DSCATT'.

span.span: 3) Statistical record-keeping by the Australian Federal Government for all Tick-borne infections definitively acquired in Australia.

p.span: The Government does not collect information on the nature of specific referrals by infectious disease specialists, therefore, statistical record-keeping by the Government for all tick-borne infections definitively acquired in Australia is at present not feasible or practical.

The National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System, which is legally underpinned by the National Health Security Act 2007, coordinates national surveillance data for diseases on the National Notifiable Disease List (NNDL). These notifiable diseases are those that present a risk to public health if there is an outbreak. A decision to list a disease on the NNDL is a matter for the Communicable Disease Network Australia, a standing committee of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

To support people experiencing various symptoms potentially attributable to ticks, the department has funded a number of projects investigating novel causes of, and potential new treatments for, tick-borne illnesses acquired in Australia. Further information on these projects, including preliminary results, can be found at www.health.gov.au, using the search term 'DSCATT'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Cashless Payment Systems
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the former Treasurer, the Hon Josh Frydenberg, concerning Petition EN2315 on businesses to accept all legal tender including cash. As the petition was not addressed by the previous Government, your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
I acknowledge the unique challenges cashless payment systems can create for older Australians and people with a disability.

While Australian banknotes and coins both continue to carry legal tender status under the Reserve Bank Act 1959 and the Currency Act 1965 respectively, a refusal to accept legal tender banknotes and/or coins is not unlawful. Providers of goods and services are able to specify what forms of payment they will accept prior to entering into a contract or transaction. If a provider specifies other means of payment prior to the contract or transaction, then there is no obligation for legal tender banknotes or coins to be accepted as payment.
It is not the intention of the Government to alter these long standing arrangements. I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
COVID-19: Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, enclosing Petition EN3882, with 251 signatures, concerning a request to process on hand subclass 887 Skilled Regional visa applications in chronological order. This correspondence has now been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Reducing the number of on hand visa applications is a priority for the Australian Government. On 1 and 2 September 2022 at the Jobs and Skills Summit, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP made a range of announcements including $36.1M to fund an extra 500 positions that have been supporting temporary and migration visa processing undertaken by the Department of Home Affairs to reduce on-hand visa applications. Good progress has been made, and as at 31 March 2023, the Department had finalised almost four times more applications for Skilled—Regional (Provisional and Permanent) visas (subclasses 489, 491 and 887), when compared to the same period in 2021-22.

The Government is aware of the significant backlog of subclass 887 visa applications that existed until recent months. The subclass 887 visa is the second stage of a two stage visa, which is available to people who already hold an eligible provisional visa and who are already working and living in regional Australia. All applicants for the subclass 887 visa, that apply while in Australia, are granted a bridging visa that allows them to continue to reside and work in Australia, until their subclass 887 visa is decided.

Skilled migration visa applications are processed according to priorities set through Ministerial Direction 100. Priority is given to applicants from outside Australia to encourage them to enter Australia and join the labour force. As subclass 887 visa applications are not made in relation to a specific occupation they are accorded a lower order of priority under this Direction.

Prior to the introduction of Ministerial Direction 100, subclass 887 visa applications were not subject to any priority processing. Ministerial Direction 100 came into effect on 28 October 2022 and replaced both Ministerial Direction 96 and 97, which were in place from 4 April 2022. Neither Ministerial Direction 96 nor 97, applied to the subclass 887 visa, which meant that they were afforded no priority and were only processed after all other visas listed under these directions.

Ministerial Direction 100 assists in reducing processing times across caseloads and allows the Department to consider applications which were not prioritised under the previous directions, including subclass 887 visa applications.

The Department is undertaking a range of measures to reduce the processing times for this type of application, and additional resources have been assigned to the caseload. I am pleased to advise that the Department has significantly reduced the subclass 887 visa backlog, by granting more than 15,000 applicants since 1 January 2023.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3882 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Immigration Detention
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, enclosing Petition EN3920, with 5,349 signatures, concerning the release of Mr Mehdi Ali and other transitory persons from immigration detention. I apologise for the delay in responding.
At the time of this petition, many transitory persons brought to Australia for a temporary purpose to receive medical treatment were detained, notably in

alternative places of detention, including hotels, often for extended periods. Some transitory persons brought to Australia under the medevac provisions in 2019 were detained for more than 2.5 years pending completion of their medical treatment,
a return to a regional processing country, or a departure from Australia.

Since May 2022, the current Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, and I, have reviewed the circumstances of individuals in held detention to ensure detention is proportional, lawful and remains necessary. We have asked the Department of Home Affairs to refer cases for our respective public interest intervention powers consideration. Home Affairs Portfolio Ministers have personal intervention powers under the Migration Act 1958, which allow them to grant a visa to a person, if they think it is in the public interest to do so. The personal intervention powers are non-compellable, that is, the Ministers are not required to exercise their power. Further, what is in the public interest is a matter for the Ministers to determine.

This action is not only a more humane approach to managing transitory persons temporarily in Australia, but ensures that immigration detention is used only where necessary and that alternatives to detention are prioritised for individuals who do not present a risk to the Australian public.
As reported in the media, Mr Ali was released from immigration detention in March 2022, and has subsequently resettled in the United States.

The Australian Government is committed to delivering orderly and legal pathways to Australia through robust migration and humanitarian programs. While a humane approach to irregular migration is required, we must also ensure that new people smuggling ventures do not reach our shores. As such, the Government has committed to maintaining strong border protection measures, including regional processing, and is upholding the policy setting that individuals who attempt to travel to Australia irregularly by boat will not settle in Australia.

Equally, the Government is focused on finding durable migration outcomes for transitory persons under regional processing and continues to support the implementation of third country resettlement arrangements with the United States and New Zealand, and providing logistical support to independent resettlement options, such as private sponsorship in Canada. Third country resettlement provides the best available opportunity for individuals to achieve permanent migration outcomes and start the next phase of their lives. Transitory persons are strongly encouraged to engage with available migration options and can access support to help them connect with their options.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3920 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Immigration Detention
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs enclosing Petition EN3933, with 162 signatures, concerning "Indefinite detention of refugees". As the current Minister for Home Affairs and Cyber Security your correspondence has been referred to me as this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Under the Migration Act 1958 (the Act), detention is not limited by a set timeframe; rather, it ends when the person is either granted a visa or is removed from Australia. This is dependent upon a number of factors, including identity determination, developments in country information and the complexity of processing due to individual circumstances relating to health, character or security matters.

The Act creates a statutory framework regulating the entry and stay of non-citizens in Australia. Under the Act, non-citizens who do not hold a visa are liable for detention. The duration and conditions of immigration detention are subject to regular review by senior officers of the Department of Home Affairs, as well as the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Australian Human Rights Commission.

The most common reasons individuals are in detention for extended periods of time are national security risks or serious criminality, unresolved identity, or health issues that cannot be managed in the community.

Immigration detention is used as a last resort. Whenever possible, unlawful non-citizens are accommodated in the community or in less restrictive alternative places of detention, in particular where children are involved. Detainees have access to appropriate food (accommodating specific medical, dietary and cultural requirements), educational programs, cultural, recreational and sporting activities, internet and computer facilities, televisions, and clean, comfortable sleeping quarters.

The Department and the ABF invests a significant amount of resources to provide high quality facilities, amenities and a broad range of services and activities within the Immigration Detention Network in order to ensure safety and security for detainees and staff.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3933 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Immigration Detention
Dear Ms Templeman,

Thank you for the correspondence of 31 March 2022 from your office enclosing Petition EN3945, with 132 signatures, concerning freedom for refugees. The correspondence was addressed to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs. This correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.
The Migration Act 1958 (the Act) creates a statutory framework regulating the entry and stay of non-citizens in Australia. Under the Act, non-citizens who do not hold
a visa are liable for detention. However, immigration detention is used as a last resort and where possible, non-citizens are managed in the community pending resolution of their status.

The decision to place a person in held immigration detention is based on an assessment of risk. The length and conditions of immigration detention are subject to regular review by senior officers of the Department of Home Affairs, as well as external independent review by the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Australian Human Rights Commission.

These reviews consider the lawfulness and appropriateness of a person's detention, their detention arrangements and placement, health and welfare, and other matters relevant to their ongoing detention and case resolution.
Under the Act, detention is not limited by a set timeframe; rather, it ends when the person is either granted a visa or is removed from Australia.

The Australian Government always seeks to resolve the status of detainees in the shortest timeframe practicable. However, this is dependent upon a number of factors, including the level of cooperation of detainees towards immigration processes, or case complexity in relation to health, character or security matters. When a person has no ongoing immigration matters they are expected to depart Australia. Non-citizens whose immigration matters are 'finally determined', including those who may have an expired visa or may need help to plan their departure from Australia, are encouraged to contact the Department's Status Resolution Service. Information about the service is available on the Department's website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/what-we-do/status-resolution- service/status-resolution-support-services.

The Department continues to explore a range of measures aimed at addressing barriers to status resolution and associated risks of long-term detention. The time an individual spends in immigration detention depends on a range of factors, including the complexity of their case, the legal processes they pursue and whether they voluntarily choose to leave Australia.

The Department can assist persons to return home voluntarily. The Return and Reintegration Assistance Program provides confidential return counselling and information, assists people to arrange travel documents and passports, provides assistance with booking flights and assistance when people arrive in their home country.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3945 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Immigration Detention
Dear Ms Templeman,
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4260, with four signatures, calling for a change in Australia's asylum seekers policy. I apologise the delay in responding.

Australia is a cohesive, multicultural society of people drawn from a rich variety of cultural backgrounds. The Australian Government knows the important social and economic contribution migrants and refugees have had through our nation's history. The Government is committed to delivering orderly and legal pathways to Australia through robust migration and humanitarian programs.

While a humane approach to irregular migration is required, we must also ensure that new people smuggling ventures do not reach our shores. As such, the Government has committed to maintaining strong border protection measures, including regional processing. Under this approach, people who attempt to travel to Australia irregularly by boat will not be settled in Australia

Australia is party to various international human rights treaties, including the 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol, International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. Australia takes its international obligations seriously and is committed to upholding them.

Transitory persons in Nauru are not detained and are living and working in the Nauruan community. They have ongoing access to health and welfare services, including mental health, delivered by a multi-disciplinary team of health practitioners, including general practitioners, nurses and counselling specialists. Specialist health services include psychology, psychiatry, dentistry, obstetrics, radiography and pharmaceutical services are also available. Where clinically indicated specialist medical treatment is not available in Nauru, mechanisms are in place for temporary transfer to a third country for assessment and treatment.

Independent organisations, including the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the International Committee of the Red Cross, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights have conducted monitoring visits in Nauru.

I can assure you that the Government is committed to finding durable migration outcomes for individuals under regional processing and we continue to support the implementation of third country resettlement arrangements with the United States and New Zealand. Over 1,080 individuals have already resettled in the United States, as well as 13 individuals in New Zealand, with a sizeable number pursuing New Zealand as a resettlement pathway. The Government is also aware of transitory persons exploring private sponsorship in Canada and is providing logistical interview and travel assistance to Canada to progress these cases.

Individuals under regional processing arrangements have lived with uncertainty about their future since they arrived in 2013-14, and resettlement in a third country provides a permanent migration outcome not available here. Individuals are strongly encouraged to engage with available migration options. Third country resettlement provides the best available opportunity for individuals to build a path to a new life.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4260 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
COVID-19: Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4327, with two signatures, concerning the impact of COVID-19 on temporary visa holders and pathways to permanent residency for temporary visa holders. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Skilled migrants play an important role in nation building, cultural diversity and social cohesion, as well as contributing significant economic benefits. The Skilled visa programs are designed to ensure that overseas workers supplement but do not displace Australian workers. Australia's universal, non-discriminatory migration programs are designed to support a safe, prosperous and united Australia.

The Temporary Skills Shortage (TSS) visa program is the primary mechanism for temporary skilled workers to Australia. The program is intended to be flexible and responsive to the economic cycle in line with employer demand to fill genuine vacancies where an Australian worker is not available.
From 1 July 2022, legislative changes were made to enable a pathway to permanent residence for:
Existing TSS (subclass 482) visa holders in the short-term stream; and
Legacy Temporary Work Skilled (subclass 457) visa holders who no longer meet the age requirement.

This is a special concession recognising those highly skilled migrant workers who chose to stay in Australia throughout the pandemic, while continuing to address Australia's acute shortages. This allows them to stay here, with a pathway to Australian citizenship.
On 13 February 2023, the Department of Home Affairs advised that this pathway is also available to Medium-term stream TSS visa holders with an occupation on the Regional Occupation List.
Further information can be found on the Department's website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/news-media/archive/article?itemId=1023.

As you may be aware, following the Jobs and Skills Summit on 1 and 2 September 2022, the Australian Government has also committed to expanding pathways to permanent residency for temporary skilled sponsored workers, with a view to reducing the number of workers residing indefinitely in Australia on a temporary visa.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4327 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
National Security
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4352, with five signatures, concerning Processing Time Standard for Australian Border Force (ABF).

The ABF is Australia's frontline border law enforcement agency, responsible for protecting Australia's border and enabling legitimate travel and trade. This role requires the ABF to respond to a diverse range of border risks including illicit drugs, firearms, explosives, chemical and biological agents, drug precursors, child exploitation material, goods which breach intellectual property laws, revenue evasion, and goods that do not meet accepted health or safety standards.

To deliver on this responsibility, the ABF risk assesses all cargo entering Australia, and where appropriate may place a hold on border clearance to enable further investigation. This investigation may include requests for additional documentation or physical inspection by ABF officers. Given the broad spectrum of risks and types of goods involved, it is not possible or practical to implement a specific timeframe for processing and release of this cargo. It is also not possible to provide details of why cargo has been held, as to do' so may compromise ongoing operational activity.

Section 186 of the Customs Act 1901 specifies that the expense of any examination of goods subject to customs control will be borne by the goods owner. Therefore, while the ABF seeks to minimise the impact of cargo interventions on legitimate trade by completing risk assessment and intervention activities as soon as possible, it is important for importers and exporters to make provisions for the possibility their cargo may be held by the ABF for further investigation.
Further information on the ABF's role and activities in the import and export environment can be found on the ABF website at: www.abf.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4352 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022, regarding petition number EN4508 and the validity period for the Professional Year program, English test scores and the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters' (NAATI) Credentialed Community Language (CCL) test score.

I respect the time taken by the Principal Petitioner, Mr Subramanian Vellayappan, to bring these issues to the Australian Government's attention. I would also like to acknowledge and thank the 49 individuals who took the time to sign it.

The Australian Government is committed to using English language requirements in migration legislation as a means to effectively manage immigration risk and ensure visa holders can participate fully in the Australian community. Asking certain visa applicants to provide an English language test score as prescribed in migration law is a reliable and consistent way for the Department to assess an applicant's English language proficiency.

The petition also references NAATI, and validity periods relating to CCL test scores. NAATI is an independent non-Government entity and is wholly responsible for setting the validity period for a CCL result. NAATI has confirmed that the expiry date of a pre-existing CCL result cannot be extended, and, if a result has expired, unfortunately the test would need to be taken again.

While there are no immediate plans to make changes relating to the issues raised by the Mr Vellayappan in petition number EN4508, I have asked the Department to consider this petition in the context of any future policy reforms that may occur in relation to English language testing at a time in the future.
Thank you again for bringing these matters to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Housing
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4574 about rental affordability and legislation for property investment zones.

The Albanese Government is aware that conditions in the rental market are currently very tight, with low vacancy rates and increasing rents across Australia and is supporting renters through its housing agenda, including:
Delivering the largest increase to Commonwealth Rent Assistance in more than 30 years, with a 15 per cent increase in the maximum rates at an ongoing cost of around $700 million per year.
Providing tax incentives to encourage more build-to-rent developments to boost new supply in the private rental market. ·

Increasing the National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation's liability cap by $2 billion to provide lower cost and longer-term finance to community housing providers through the Affordable Housing Bond Aggregator, supporting the delivery of more social and affordable rental housing.
Establishing the Housing Australia Future Fund, which will help support 30,000 new social and affordable rental properties in its first five years.

Providing $350 million under the National Housing Accord to support an additional 10,000 affordable dwellings, with states and territories supporting up to an additional 10,000, increasing the affordable dwellings that can be delivered under the Accord to 20,000.
Working collaboratively with state and territory governments through National Cabinet to strengthen renters' rights.
In the petition, I note the applicant is concerned about excessive rents and that legislation should be introduced to ensure that not all areas should property investment zones.

While the regulation of residential tenancies, including rental agreements and pricing is a matter for state and territory governments, I have held several meetings with my state and territory counterparts to discuss approaches they can take to address residential tenancies. I encourage the applicant to contact the Hon. Rita Saffioti MLA, the Western Australian Government Minister for Transport; Planning; Ports to discuss this matter further.
If the applicant is concerned about excessive rent increases, I suggest they contact the Western Australian tenants' advisory service through www.tenants.org.au/tu/tenants-services-australia.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Cybercrime
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence originally to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN4582—Identity protection for finance applications. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Under Australia's anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing frameworks, reporting entities (which includes credit providers) are obligated to collect information from customers and verify their identity, before commencing a designated service (which includes making a loan). This applies to both regulated and unregulated lenders, provided the loans are made in the course of carrying on a loans business.

These identity verification obligations are imposed by the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006 (AML/ITF Act). The objects of this Act include to detect, deter and disrupt money laundering, the financing of terrorism, and other serious financial crimes. This may include identity theft related financial crimes of the kind referred to by the petitioners.

Failures to comply with AML/CTF identity verification obligations may attract significant penalties. The enforcement actions available to the regulator, the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC), include civil penalty orders, enforceable undertakings, infringement notices and remedial directions. The courts may impose civil penalties orders of up to 20,000 penalty unit per breach for individuals or 100,000 penalty units for body corporates.

Credit providers who collect personal data are also generally subject to Privacy Act 1988 (Privacy Act) requirements regarding the collection, use, disclosure, quality and integrity of personal information. In particular, Australian Privacy Principle 11imposes obligations to protect personal information from misuse, interference and loss, and from authorised access, modification or disclosure.

It should be noted that in addition to any legal obligations, credit providers are strongly incentivised to ensure that borrowers are who they say they are—in order to avoid financial losses through fraud.

Where an individual is concerned that they may be a victim of fraud or identity theft in relation to lending they may, pursuant to Part IIIA of the Privacy Act, initiate a 21-day ban on credit providers or credit reporting bodies using or disclosing the information in their consumer credit report. Accordingly, the ban may prevent credit being extended by limiting credit application assessments for the ban period. Individuals can indefinitely extend this ban period if they are a victim of fraud.

Independent statutory reviews of the credit reporting provisions contained in the Privacy Act and the mandatory credit reporting framework in the National Consumer Credit Protection Act 2009 are due to be completed by October 2024. The reviews will ensure that the credit reporting framework in Australia is fit for purpose, including considering the requirements on credit providers or credit reporting bodies in situations of suspected fraud and misuse, and the effectiveness of credit bans to freeze access to an individual's credit files.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Asylum Seekers

I refer to your correspondence of 6 February 2023 to the Hon Andrew Giles MP, Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, enclosing Petition EN4613, with 456 signatures, calling for a change in Australia's asylum seekers policy. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Australia is a cohesive, multicultural society of people drawn from a rich variety of cultural backgrounds. The Australian Government knows the important social and economic contribution migrants and refugees have had through our nation's history. The Government is committed to delivering orderly and legal pathways to Australia through robust migration and humanitarian programs.

While a humane approach to irregular migration is required, we must also ensure that new people smuggling ventures do not reach our shores. As such, the Government has committed to maintaining strong border protection measures, including regional processing. Under this approach, people who attempt to travel to Australia irregularly by boat will not be settled in Australia.

Australia is party to the various international human rights treaties, including 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol, International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. Australia takes its international obligations seriously and is committed to upholding them.

Transitory persons in Nauru are not detained and are living and working in the Nauruan community. They have ongoing access to health and welfare services, including mental health, delivered by a multi-disciplinary team of health practitioners, including general practitioners, nurses and counselling specialists. Specialist health services include psychology, psychiatry, dentistry, obstetrics, radiography and pharmaceutical services are also available. Where clinically indicated specialist medical treatment is not available in Nauru, mechanisms are in place for temporary transfer to a third country for assessment and treatment.

Independent organisations, including the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the International Committee of the Red Cross, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights have conducted monitoring visits in Nauru.

I assure you the Government is committed to finding durable migration outcomes for individuals under regional processing and we continue to support the implementation of third country resettlement arrangements with the United States and New Zealand. Over 1,080 individuals have already resettled in the United States, as well as 13 individuals in New Zealand, with a sizeable number pursuing New Zealand as a resettlement pathway. The Government is also aware of transitory persons exploring private sponsorship in Canada and is providing logistical interview and travel assistance to Canada to progress these cases.

Individuals under regional processing arrangements have lived with uncertainty about their future since they arrived in 2013-14, and resettlement in a third country provides a permanent migration outcome not available here. Individuals are strongly encouraged to engage with available migration options. Third country resettlement provides the best available opportunity for individuals to build a path to a new life.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4613 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Waste Management and Recycling
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 to the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, the Hon Chris Bowen MP, about petition EN4634, funding for supporting soft plastic recycling. Your correspondence has been referred to me as Minister for the Environment and Water, as the matters raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities.

Reducing and responsibly managing Australia's plastic waste is a priority for the Australian Government. The issues facing soft plastic collection and recycling are unfortunate, but they are temporary. Coles, Woolworths and Aldi have released a roadmap that outlines the pathway to resume in store collection. The roadmap can be found on the supermarkets' websites. Industry has a lead role in improving the sustainability of plastics they use and the government will continue to support them in delivering solutions.

In addition to these immediate efforts, I expect industry to look at ways to improve the management of soft plastics into the future. Medium to long term solutions will likely include improved packaging design to ensure packaging materials are easier to recycle, new approaches to how packaging materials are collected and managed, and new technologies to recycle soft plastics back into food grade packaging or other marketable plastic products.

The Australian Government is investing $250 million into new and upgraded recycling infrastructure through the Recycling Modernisation Fund (RMF). The additional recycling capacity funded by the RMF supports Australia to regulate the export of waste glass, plastic, tyres, paper and cardboard. The RMF will see over $1 billion of investment in recycling infrastructure, with contributions from the states and territories and industry. RMF projects already announced will add over one million tonnes of processing capacity every year.

The government is investing a further $60 million for a Plastics Technology stream through the RMF. This will support advanced recycling solutions and build Australia's capability to address hard-to-recycle plastics, including soft plastics.
More information about the plastics technology stream can be found at
www.dcceew.gov.au/environment/protection/waste/how-we-manage-waste/recycling- modernisation-fund.
Thank you for bringing the Committee's concerns to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Waste Management and Recycling
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 about petition EN4640, making the change to using biodegradable soft plastics only.

Reducing and responsibly managing Australia's plastic waste is a priority for the Australian Government. The issues facing soft plastic collection and recycling are unfortunate, but they are temporary. Coles, Woolworths and Aldi have released a roadmap that outlines the pathway to resume instore collection. Industry has a lead role in improving the sustainability of plastics they use, and the government will continue to support them in delivering solutions.

In addition to these immediate efforts, I expect industry to look at ways to improve the management of soft plastics into the future. Medium to long term solutions will likely include improved packaging design to ensure packaging materials are easier to recycle, new approaches to how packaging materials are collected and managed, and new technologies to recycle soft plastics back into food grade packaging or other marketable plastic products.

There are many factors to be considered in the design and use of plastics to reduce the impact on the environment. While there is increasing interest from industry and consumers about biodegradable plastics, the term biodegradable can be misleading by implying packaging will safely degrade outside of a processing system. Some biodegradable plastics release toxic components into the environment as they degrade, fragmenting or breaking up into microplastics that further contribute to plastic pollution. There is also no requirement for products labelled as biodegradable to specify the conditions and timeframe within which the material must break down.

In contrast, compostable plastic packaging certified to Australian Standard AS4736 or AS5810 must degrade or break down within relatively short timeframes and comply with important quality and ecotoxicity criteria. Certified compostable packaging can also offer value as part of a circular economy as an alternative for single-use plastics for facilitating the recovery of food waste where it is accepted through food organic recovery systems.

It is important to recognise that there are many circumstances where recyclable plastic packaging will have a preferable outcome over biodegradable or certified compostable packaging. For example, conventional plastic packaging which can be recycled and reused multiple times in new packaging and other products has an improved life cycle outcome over biodegradable plastic which can take years to degrade and cannot be reused.

In October 2022, all Environment Ministers agreed to reform the regulation of packaging by 2025 to ensure that all packaging available in Australia is designed to be recovered, reused, recycled, and reprocessed safely in line with circular economy principles. This reform is an opportunity to mandate obligations for industry and provide a framework to support and monitor industry progress against design and circularity objectives. I am committed to working with industry and the states and territories to address barriers to achieving the targets and to have a new fit-for-purpose regulatory scheme for packaging in place by 2025.

To reduce the environmental impact of soft plastic packaging it is essential that industry both reduces the use of plastic and adopts sustainable design principles. A central pillar of the government's reform of packaging regulation will ensure industry complies with obligations for the sustainable design of soft plastic packaging. These requirements could include the use of mono-materials, an overall reduction of plastic use, only using ink and labels compatible with recycling processes, increasing the use of recycled content, and adopting the Australasian Recycling Label. The Australian Packaging Covenant Organisation's Sustainable Packaging Guidelines and the international CEFLEX soft plastics guidelines are currently available to industry as best practice models for soft plastics design.

We are committed to upgrading the existing recycling infrastructure for fossil-based plastic. The Australian Government is investing $250 million into new and upgraded recycling infrastructure through the Recycling Modernisation Fund (RMF). The additional recycling capacity funded by the RMF supports Australia to regulate the export of waste glass, plastic, tyres, paper and cardboard. The RMF will see over $1 billion of investment in recycling infrastructure, with contributions from the states and territories and industry. RMF projects already announced will add over one million tonnes of processing capacity every year.

The government is investing a further $60 million for a Plastics Technology stream through the RMF. This will support advanced recycling solutions and build Australia's capability to address hard-to-recycle plastics, including soft plastics.
More information about the plastics technology stream can be found at
www.dcceew.gov.au/environment/protection/waste/how-we-manage-waste/recycling-modernisation-fund.
Thank you again for bringing the petitioners' concerns about soft plastics to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Child Safety
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4651 on the regulation of baby walkers in Australia. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

In 2004, baby walkers were banned in Canada following a broad industry agreement to withdraw and no longer supply these products. Although banned in Canada, a number of countries continued to allow baby walkers to be supplied so long as they met specific safety standards that provide special protections to the infants using those products.

In Australia, current protections for baby walkers are mandated by the Consumer Protection Notice No. 1 of 2013—Safety Standard: Baby Walkers under the Australian Consumer Law (ACL). This mandatory safety standard requires all baby walkers supplied in Australia to comply with specific design, construction, performance and labelling requirements based on certain sections of the American Society for Testing and Materials' voluntary standard known as ASTM F977-00 Standard Consumer Safety Specification for Infant Walkers. ASTM F977-00 includes requirements that intend to reduce the risk of injury such as braking mechanisms to stop baby walkers from falling down steps or stairs, stability requirements to resist tip-over, and warning requirements pertaining to suitable use and supervision.

The Australian Consumer and Competition Commission (ACCC) periodically reviews bans and mandatory safety standards to ensure they offer appropriate protection. Given the concerns raised in this petition, I will ask the ACCC to consider these issues when they next review the mandatory safety standard for this product. Currently, the ACCC is not considering any proposals for a ban given the requirements of the mandatory safety standard which are designed to address the risks associated with the use of these products.

In addition to product-specific regulation, the ACCC has published safety information for consumers, which includes safety tips around supervision and appropriate use, following a coordinated surveillance project with state and territory consumer law regulators. Further guidance for consumers can be found on the Product Safety Australia website.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
HomeBuilder
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4691 on the HomeBuilder grant document cut-off date. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Albanese Government understands that matters outside of Australians' control have led to the disruption of the construction industry and supply lines, and as a result has impacted the ability of some existing HomeBuilder applicants to meet the 30 April 2023 deadline for providing supporting documentation.

On 27 April 2023, I announced that I had signed a revised National Partnership Agreement on HomeBuilder (NPA) on behalf of the Commonwealth. The revised NPA extends the deadline for document submission from 30 April 2023 to 30 June 2025.

This extension will only apply to existing applicants who had entered financial commitments on the basis they would receive the grant but, through no fault of their own, were affected by supply constraints and construction industry delays.

This extension will provide sufficient time for all outstanding applicants to complete the eligibility requirements to receive the HomeBuilder grant. The eligibility requirements for the HomeBuilder program will remain the same.
The revised NPA will apply in a state or territory whose government also signs the revised NPA.

I can advise that the following states have signed the revised NPA, and the extended deadline is now in operation in Western Australia, Tasmania, South Australia, Australian Capital Territory, and Queensland.
Updates on when state and territory governments agree to the revised NPA will be made at the Treasury HomeBuilder website at treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/homebuilder.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Taxation: Online Fundraising
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4696 on applying tests for the true purpose of money raised during online fund raisers. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Australia's present state and territory fundraising laws were developed at a time when most fundraising was conducted in person. With most fundraising done online, the costs and complexities of complying with multiple state and territory fundraising requirements is a major issue for the charity sector, and uncertainty about the oversight of short term, quickfire fundraising campaigns is a source of confusion for donors.

For years, it's been clear we need to fix Australia's outdated fundraising laws. Nationally consistent fundraising regulation has been recommended by several reviews over the past decade, including the 2020 Royal Commission into National Natural Disaster Arrangements formed in response to the extreme bushfire season of 2019-20.

Earlier this year, I was pleased to announce the first step in modernising our charitable fundraising regulations. The Commonwealth, state and territory Treasurers have agreed to a set of nationally consistent fundraising principles to streamline and harmonise state and territory requirements on charitable fundraiser conduct.
In relation to the specific concern raised in Petition EN4696, Australian tax law effectively creates a purpose test for funds raised through online fundraising platforms.

Money received through an online fundraising platform is assessable income and liable to income tax if the fundraising is in the course of employment, run in a businesslike way with the intent of making a profit or received in the ordinary course of business. However, if the money received is a genuine gift—for example, to cover a medical procedure for an individual—it will not be assessable income and will not be subject to income tax.

If a fundraiser is a charity registered with the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission (ACNC), the charity must be able to show that it uses its income to pursue its charitable purposes. Failure to do so may result in the ACNC revoking its registration which would result in the charity losing its tax exemption.

Other not-for-profit organisations are exempt from income tax only if they apply their income and assets for specific purposes set out in tax law, such as promoting sport. From 2023-24, such organisations will need to prove to the Australian Taxation Office their eligibility for the income tax exemption.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Dr Leigh
Sudden Cardiac Arrest
Dear Chair,
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 regarding petition number EN4699, which proposed mandatory requirements for businesses to have an Automated External Defibrillator (AED).

The Commonwealth shares responsibility for work, health and safety (WHS) with the states and territories, with each jurisdiction responsible for implementing, regulating and enforcing their own WHS laws. WHS laws are largely harmonised across these jurisdictions through a set of uniform laws (the model WHS laws, which includes a model Act, model Regulations and model Codes of Practice). All jurisdictions except Victoria have implemented the model WHS laws, and Victoria has similar laws in place. Changes to the model WHS laws require a two-third majority of WHS Ministers to support the changes, after which each jurisdiction is responsible for replicating the changes into their own WHS laws.

Under the model WHS laws, persons conducting a business or undertaking (PCBU), such as an employer, have a duty to ensure that all persons in the workplace, including workers and other persons, are not exposed to health and safety risks. This duty requires risks to health and safety to be eliminated or minimised as far as is reasonably practicable. The model WHS Regulations contain an additional duty on a PCBU to provide first aid, including providing first aid equipment for the workplace. The composition of this equipment is not prescribed, but may include an AED.

The model Codes of Practice provide practical guidance to assist duty holders to meet their requirements under the model WHS laws. In practice, a duty holder must comply with a Code of Practice unless the duty holder has an alternative method of compliance at a standard that is equivalent to or higher than the Code of Practice.

Safe Work Australia's Model Code of Practice: First aid in the workplace recommends that PCBUs apply a risk management approach to their first aid obligations. Key considerations include the nature of the work, the nature of hazards present in the workplace, size, location and nature of the workplace and the number and composition of workers and other persons. The Code recommends that PCBUs should consider providing an AED if there is a risk from electrocution, if there would be a delay in ambulance services arriving at the workplace, or where there are large numbers of members of the public.

A copy of the model Code of Practice on first aid and further information about PCBU first aid duties can be found on Safe Work Australia's website www.safeworkaustralia.gov.au/doc/model-code-practice-first-aid-workplace.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke
Census and Statistics Act 1905
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence on 18 May 2023 concerning the petition (EN4848) to make changes to the Census and Statistics Act 1905 to legally mandate the inclusion of LGBTIQA+ data within the Census.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) is currently reviewing the topics and questions that will be collected in the 2026 Census of Population and Housing. The details of this petition will be included into the first round of consultation.

The ABS is currently assessing information needs identified during the first round of consultation against the published assessment criteria. The ABS will then undertake a second round of consultation mid-year on the topics being considered for inclusion, change or removal from the 2026 Census. ·
Further information on the 2026 Census topic review process can be found on the ABS website
www.abs.gov.au/census/2026-census-topic-review. You can also subscribe to receive updates regarding the topic review process at www.subscribe.abs.qov.au/2026Census.
I have copied this letter to the Treasurer, the Hon Dr Jim Chalmers MP. I trust this information will be of assistance.
CC: The Treasurer, the Hon Dr Jim Chalmers MP.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Dr Leigh
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence on 18 May 2023 concerning the petition (EN4862} to add COVID-19 vaccination status as a question to the 2026 Census.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS} is currently reviewing the topics and questions that will be collected in the 2026 Census of Population and Housing. The details of this petition will be included into the first round of consultation.

The ABS is currently assessing information needs identified during the first round of consultation against the published assessment criteria. The ABS will then undertake a second round of consultation mid-year on the topics being considered for inclusion, change or removal from the 2026 Census.
Further information on the 2026 Census topic review process can be found_ on the ABS website
www.abs.qov.au/census/2026-census-topic-review. You can also subscribe to receive updates regarding the topic review process at www.subscribe.abs.qov.au/2026Census.
I have copied this letter to the Treasurer, the Hon Dr Jim Chalmers MP.
I trust this information will be of assistance.
CC: The Treasurer, the Hon Dr Jim Chalmers MP.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Dr Leigh
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): Since its introduction in the 45th Parliament, petitioners have enthusiastically embraced the House of Representatives e-petition system as an effective way of bringing their issue or concern to the House. Electronic petitions hosted on the parliamentary website allow Australian citizens and residents to easily share and gather support for their petitions across Australia and beyond. Support for electronic petitioning has increased to the point where, in the current parliament to date, more than 97 per cent of petitions presented in the House have been submitted through the e-petition system. However, some petitioners continue to choose pen and paper to bring their requests to the House. One benefit of paper petitions is that they allow petitioners to go out into their communities and engage with people face to face. The process of collecting handwritten signatures provides organisers with an opportunity to discuss the matters raised in the petition and to gauge the level of community support behind an issue.

As you can see, I've presented one that has significant community support. Today I presented a paper petition organised by the community group Grandmothers for Refugees, which is active in many electorates, including in my electorate of Macquarie in New South Wales, Fremantle in Western Australia and Higgins in Victoria. This petition, asking the House to take certain actions to support people seeking asylum in Australia, has gathered 6,556 signatures. These signatures were collected across Australia at community events, markets, shopping centres and coffee shops. I also note that a petition from Grandmothers for Refugees with around 1,800 signatures collected at events during 2022 and 2023, largely within my electorate of Macquarie, wasn't compliant with the petition rules, so I have personally written to the minister, providing details of the request to government on a range of steps the petitioners would like to see. To all the grandmothers involved in this advocacy across the country, I'd like to commend them on an incredible effort.
I thank the House.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Interactive Gambling Amendment (Ban on Gambling Advertisements) Bill 2023

p.span: Interactive Gambling Amendment (Ban on Gambling Advertisements) Bill 2023
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Ms Sharkie.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (10:04): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Australians are fed up with being bombarded by gambling advertisements.
We are sick and tired of seeing people, including our young people, treated as revenue streams by gambling companies, sporting codes and governments.
We have reached the point where seven out of 10 Australians agree that gambling advertising should be banned.
I don't understand why everyday Australians are having to push leaders who are resistant to this change. This should already be law.
That is why I am introducing my Interactive Gambling Amendment (Ban on Gambling Advertisements) Bill 2023.

I appreciate the member for Clark's support in seconding this bill and his tireless advocacy for reducing gambling harm, and also the support of Senator Lambie and Senator Pocock for this bill in the other place.

This bill would amend the Interactive Gambling Act 2001 to ban advertising of licensed interactive gambling services such as telephone and online gambling, whether on television, radio, in print or online.
This ban does not cover excluded wagering or lottery services.
Further, exemptions are provided for political communications, business document, and antigambling advertisements (including gambling harm reduction advertisements).
And publication, broadcast or datacasting which is accidental or incidental is permitted, as are publication, broadcasting or datacasting in other limited circumstances.
Expanding the existing bans on gambling advertising is justified given gambling harm is now a glaring public health issue.
Australians lost more than $25 billion in 2018-19 on gambling, causing untold mental, social and financial harm to individuals, families, workplaces and communities.
This figure has undoubtedly increased since that time, given the dramatic growth reported in the interactive gambling sector during COVID and with the advent of people using their phones.
Online and telephone services now enable people to lose their homes while they are sitting in their homes.

With gambling companies spending $287.2 million on gambling ads in 2022, and an average of 948 gambling advertisements airing per day on free-to-air television alone in Victoria, we have reached saturation point. It is ridiculous.
Enough is enough.

We know that Australians are increasingly targeted by gambling advertising, which is particularly targeted at young people, who are being told to bet with their mates—quirky advertising that's funky and focused on young people.
The Australian Institute of Family Studies has found that three in four Australians have gambled at least once in the past year, with almost half of them at risk of harm from betting.
The institute's 2023 report highlights concerning links between gambling advertising and increased betting.
As I said, young people in particular are reportedly more likely to bet on impulse or gamble more after viewing these ads. These ads are overwhelmingly targeted at them.

It's pretty sad when we get to a point where kids know all about this. They know about all the apps. They ask their parents if they've got the apps, whether they can place a bet. And a thousand times a day—we are kidding ourselves if we don't think this is causing harm.

We need to wean governments and sporting codes off their reliance on gambling revenue. And we need to provide adequate supports for the mental, social and financial wellbeing of individuals and families in our society who are suffering from gambling harm.
We need to show some leadership, ban predatory gambling advertising and develop evidence based strategies to treat gambling harm as a public health issue, instead of treating people like cash cows.

I look back in time to 1992. That was the time when in this place we banned cigarette advertising. It's a legal product if you're over 18 years of age, but we recognised the public health harm of this. Since then, the major political parties have not accepted donations from cigarette companies. We need to do the same with gambling. We need to see this as an inherent harm, and particularly harming our young people. And it's going to take some courage by government to do this, but I say: let's be like 1992; let's make that have been in this place, because it is equally harmful. It is a public health issue—it's actually a public health emergency. I know there are young people who are harming, who have taken their lives because they've just got so much into debt, or who can't even watch a game of sport anymore for the constant bombardment of advertisements. And it's on all the channels, and that's why this bill will target it, whether it's on free-to-air, on radio, in print or, indeed, on streaming services and social media. We need to make sure that there's no corner that allows this to continue to happen.
I would like to provide the rest of my time to the member for Clark, who is seconding this bill. I commend this bill to the House.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?

Mr WILKIE (Clark) (10:10): I'm very pleased to second the motion for the second reading of the member for Mayo's bill, the Interactive Gambling Amendment (Ban on Gambling Advertisements) Bill 2023, because, quite frankly, Australians are sick to death of gambling advertising. It's no wonder, when the study commissioned by the Victorian Responsible Gambling Foundation found that more than 70 per cent of Australians want gambling advertising banned, and there's no wonder why, almost every day, members of the community tell me they're well and truly over watching gambling being promoted and normalised, often diminishing their enjoyment of sport and impacting dangerously on their children.

That last point matters so very much, because way too often Australian children are bombarded with targeted advertising campaigns on billboards, on sports uniforms, on the TV and on their phones and other devices. Good grief, the adverts are everywhere. Nor, of course, is this just a matter of spoiling the game. No. Ultimately, the more the predatory gambling companies advertise, the more they prey on the vulnerable and the more they stoke addiction, just like the tobacco companies once did. Frankly, we mustn't forget the enormous human cost of problem gambling. Indeed, as the member for Goldstein noted when introducing a similar bill last month, the estimated social cost of gambling in 2017 was $7 billion.

Of course, such figures are well known—we've heard them time and time again—but it seems the government needs a reminder of the real impact that gambling has. For instance, take Gavin Fineff, the former financial adviser who gambled and lost $8 million of his clients' money, with the willing assistance of three of Australia's biggest online betting agencies. Yes, Gavin understands he did the wrong thing and is now in jail, but he is not the only one to blame, because the predatory practices of Tabcorp, Ladbrokes and BetEasy facilitated and encouraged Gavin's gambling addiction. They offered him VIP status, bonus bets and tickets to sporting events. But, unconscionably, none of these companies once asked where the money was coming from. Indeed, they even facilitated accounts under a false name to allow him to continue gambling.

That this madness continues and that almost all the political parties remain beholden to gambling companies really does beggar belief, but I suppose it's not difficult to understand why when you consider the report by the Centre for Public Integrity, which shows $24 million in donations from the gambling industry to the major parties over the past two decades.
